The charge has held for 5 uses so far - which is great if you don't want to carry the power adapter with you when travelling.
  444. I bought this after reading all the rave reviews, and having quite satisfactorily previously owned a Remington beard trimmer years and years ago. It was the biggest mistake I could make. This trimmer will *damage* longer beards. My beard is just over the length of the 8 setting on this, and while the trimmer was powerful and comfortable, a day after using it, my entire beard was completely and irreparably damaged. Where the Remington cuts the hairs is fine - the cuts are clean and straight, not resulting in any split ends. But if your beard hairs are even remotely stiff/brittle and thick, it will \\"break\\" them in multiple spots. It appears that the blades are \\"messy,\\" they will do half-cuts in more than one place along a hair. I'm not talking about one or two hairs here - a week after my \\"trim,\\" I've had to manually cull thousands of hairs and am still finding more that have been completely ruined. The only fix at this point is a clean shave and two months regrowth. Don't get this if you don't feel like going clean shaven for a week in order to regrow your hair after this abomination of a trimmer damages it. It works fine if you're using it to shave rather than trim, or if you're using it on sparse hair (mustaches vs beards).
  445. I bought this on sale for $15 at a local Kroger (Smiths) outlet just to quickly replace my $50 trimmer that started to pinch and I have been very impressed with it for the price I paid. I've had it 6 months now and it works just like it did when I bought it. Some things I like about this particular model: #1 - NO ATTACHMENTS! Can't tell you how many times I've had to fumble and look through my stash to find the correct attachment to use. This completely defeats this problem by just using a scroll wheel to select what length of trim you want. #2 - Charge indicator light, believe it or not some don't have any charge indication lights which makes it real fun to try to determine if the device is charging or is fully charged. #3 - No pinching. Like I said, I've had it for 6 months and it still cuts great and I have thick black hair. I've spent $50-$70 only to get a unit that pinches and pulls on hairs rather than trim them. You can't go wrong with this unit, its cheap and it works better than some of the more expensive units you can find. This is one case where price isn't a indication of quality.

  449. So I picked this trimmer for the following reasons:<br /><br />- no oiling/ maintenance free<br />- cordless, but rechargeable<br />- low price point<br />- number of positive reviews<br /><br />After giving it an initial try here's what I've come up with:<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />-Its relatively easy to use, even it the angling is a bit awkward. The adjustment mechanism feels good and it is easy to see what number it is on.<br />- Worked well for its intended purpose<br />- seems to be made well enough, especially for the price<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />-Though it doesn't mention one anyway, there was no stand for the unit, which is a little inconvenient.<br />- You cannot use it while it is plugged in. Rather you can, but it wont power the unit. The actual adapter looks like a 3.5 mm headphone jack and plug. Its a bit unusual and I assume that its the reason why it cant be used \\"pass thru\\".<br />- No warning when power dips too low for use. When I first opened it I tried to test it out without charging. It started fine, but then suddenly slowed to an unusable rate. It appears to have a light on it, but I didn't notice it on when this happened.<br />- While it has quite a number of adjustments, unfortunately the gaps between may be a bit extreme for some people. Also I found that on the lowest setting it wasn't as short as I'd like to see. I ended up using a 4 for the bulk of the trimming, but I will still require the use of my Braun electric for touching up.<br />-Angle is awkward to handle. I found it hard to make consistent strokes due to the severe angle of the head, luckily it doesn't affect the results, just the comfort of use.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />Overall I think if you maintain any facial hair this is a great tool, however don't expect it to be a one stop tool. That being said it trimmer very well, with no tugging or jamming (my beard is pretty thick). I cant speak for the maintenance free area. They include a small brush to clean out the head, so depending on how you feel, that may be much for you. I found after one charged use it required it (it retains a lot of hair). It would appear it would require it every use, which is a little annoying, but is depended on your habits and usage too.ins a lot of hair). It would appear it would require it every use, which is a little annoying, but is depended on your habits and usage too.

  467. Works very well for trimming beards to 9 lengths including a close stubble look. The down side is the battery, NiCD, which suffers from memory effect if improperly charged. If you find a trimmer for about the same price with Lithium or NiMH batteries then get that since they are fool-proof to charge. If you're willing to put up with properly charging this and the price is right, you'll be happy with this one. Like I said it performs very well. NiCD batteries should be fully drained before charging, and fully charged before using; otherwise the battery life will shorten and if done a number of times the battery will stop holding a charge. (I'm guessing reviewers who say the battery stops working after a couple weeks didn't do this) Also during use, NiCD batteries provide steady power until they run out suddenly with little warning. The problem with that is the charge time is 14 to 16 hours, which means even if you use the trimmer the night before, if the battery dies you can't finish the job in the morning without fear of shortening the life of the battery somewhat. But overall it performs very well and if charged properly should work for years and is very cheap; so I only took off 1 star.
  468. I like this trimmer just fine, I dropped my 1st one in the sink and broke the plastic adjustment tab off. I just saved the cutting head off it for a spare on my new trimmer and tossed the rest.
  469. I turn on the trimmer and about 5 seconds later it turns off due to not holding a charge. I've been trying to charge since then, its definitely not a user error; the battery no longer holds a charge. I would not suggest this product to a friend.

  488. Some of the complaints are legit - it does not hold a great charge and it has some cheap pieces on it. The good news is that the defects are easily remedied - don't drop it on the floor, keep it charged and it's the best trimmer ever for the dirt cheap price of $29.99. After two years, it's still running strong. UPDATE: Had some problems during year 3 - mostly about charging. Now, I drain the charge completely before re-charging. Only 1, 1 1/2 shaves per charge but I only trim my beard once per week so it still works fine.
  489. Thanks.... I love this one. I have had a few different brands types over the years, but this one really works... We'll see how long it lasts...
  490. I just bought this to replace a larger trimmer I have had for a few years. I like this model a lot. The cutting length guide is small enough to easily trim under your chin and above your lip. There are no attachments, just the attached guide. I prefer it that way. I am tried of getting a bunch of plastic crap with every trimmer I buy when I just use one piece. It cuts hair well without tugging or pain. The adjustment wheel is like a mouse scroll wheel and functions a lot easier and smoother than most crude \\"snapping\\" adjustments on other trimmers. The only problem is that the guide doesn't appear to lock in place. Granted it takes a reasonable amount of force to adjust it and I don't think you will adjust it by pressing up against your face, but you could potentially bump / roll the wheel and adjust it inadvertently. I like the prodcut a lot for facial hair trimming. I have used 4 or 5 trimmers over the years and this is the best. It's pretty cheap too.
  491. Even after reading some of the weak reviews, I figured there would be no harm in spending about $30 on a beard trimmer. Howeverm like a lot of the other feedback, this shaver worked about 10 times, before promptly dying after being turned for 3 seconds each time. I do want to note that I charged it overseas (where I live) using an adapter. This has never impacted any other appliances I've purchased, but I did want to note it. My recommendation: spend a few more $$'s, and get something that will last
  492. This product has worked well for me. Get a close shave with just a little stubble left. I've used it 4 or 5 times now without having to recharge it after the initial charge.   493. This is a wonderful trimmer. While it is a little light weight and hums a little too loud, this trimmer is perfect. Allows you to trim at a good lenght - setting 10 - and anywhere in between.   494. I really enjoyed this trimmer while it lasted. I had to keep it plugged in, but it *really* cut through hair fast and efficiently. I'm only not using it now because the click knob to change hair length broke and the guide would no longer move up or down appropriately. One problem with the trimmer is it never was good at giving the 2 day stub look. Before I grew out a full beard I found this lack of a feature bothersome. As your beard get's closer to a size 3.5 this trimmer totally loses effectiveness -- I find the hairs near the chin to be substantially longer than the hairs on the cheek.<br /><br />For $7.00 more I'm going to order the HC-5550 this time around.

  501. I bought in December 2012. And I was quite happy at the beginning. Namely, one evening I’ve started trimming my mustache but it stopped after I trimmed only my left side. I plugged it in the outlet hoping to continue, but it does not work this way. As soon as you turn it on - it stops charging and switches back to using (uncharged) battery again. In short I had to wait about 15 minutes before I could trim my right side. I had my 15 years old Panasonic (before I bought this Remington) and I actually never charged my Panasonic because I always plugged it while trimming. Things got worse when battery got very weak. Now I have to charge it for 30 min every time right before I use it, and I have about 2 min to trim my mustache, otherwise I need to charge it again to finish the job.<br /><br />I won’t buy any trimmer from Remington again and don’t suggest to anyone to buy it.

  504. Both this to replacement my old Remington. It was old. The battery died long ago but could still be used while plugged in. It was just time for a new one.<br /><br />Bought this in the end of February and six months later it will not hold a charge. I gave it a full days charge when unpacked, didn't let it sit dead, or abuse it in anyway.<br />What really bothers me is that they changed the design so the shaver will ONLY pull from the battery. The plug is for charging only. Once the battery goes the shaver will not work when plugged in. This type of design change can not be considered an accident. It seems to be the typical \\"design it to fail and consumers will have to replace more often increasing sales\\" mentality that has swept through many companies over the last couple decades.<br /><br />Never again Remington. You lost a long time and brand faithful customer.

The only decent thing about the trimmer is that it has numerous adjustable increments in the lower length end.   520. First off, this is a great trimmer at what it is meant for: trimming your beard/mustache. I was very satisfied with the trim it delivered; it was easy to set the length and the setting stayed in place. The blades seemed to be nice and sharp, it provided a smooth trim and didn't pull any hairs or otherwise cause any discomfort. The reason I am rating this 4 stars is because it can be a bit messy to use. When using this trimmer, because there is no vacuum function the hairs literally go all over the bathroom sink and this can cause clogs if you just flush everything down the drain. I actually have stopped using this and am using a competing product that contains a vacuum that sucks all cut hairs into a container for easy disposal in the trash. Overall, this is still a very good product, I just can't rate it 5 stars because I feel it could use the extra feature of a vacuum suction. If you don't need this feature, there's no reason not to purchase this trimmer.

  528. This trimmer has great battery life. I have used it for over 30 minutes out of the box and have not yet needed to charge it.<br /><br />The built-in adjustable trimmer is a nice feature, but I don't have a beard--I use it to trim my sideburns in between barber visits. However, I noticed that it is a bit difficult to adjust the wheel when my hands are damp. The rubberized wheel is great when your hands area dry, but impossible to adjust when damp.<br /><br />The power switch is also a bit difficult to use with damp hands. they should have added some bumps or ridges to the switch to make turning it on easier.<br /><br />Finally, if you're using this without the trimming guide, the clippers are not flush with each other, so you may not be able to achieve razor-sharp trims.<br /><br />Overall, a well-built trimmer, but it has a few flaws.

  536. I bought this trimmer after dropping my previous one from a different brand. The cheap plastic height modulator shattered and the only way to control the depth was to tape it in one place. The height wheel makes it exceedingly easy to switch how close you want to trim, and it's all very solid. Others have mentioned that there is no charging stand, but that is a plus for me as those things can topple over anyway. Or at least they seem to if I get within a yard of them. I much prefer to lie it down where it can't fall. It's also very, very easy to clean. Overall, I would definitely recommend this product. For the money, you really can't go wrong.   539. I have had this trimmer for over a year now.   541. I bought this because my father had one for a while and said it worked well. Guess what - it does. I wanted something rechargeable, simple, that could give me a 'stubble' look. The product works great - just set it to the lowest setting and voila, take off the plastic head cover for an even closer detailing. The battery life is fantastic - charged it when I got it, have been using it maybe twice a week for a month now? Maybe more? Still haven't had to recharge it. Cleaning is easy - shake it, pop open the top, and use the supplied brush to empty any hair.<br /><br />One design flaw - when you flip open the top to clean it, the top is only attached by a small plastic hinge. I have been careful and haven't had any problems, but I can see that a bit too much force will snap it off. Be careful and you will be fine, but don't let your kids play with it.<br /><br />In summary: very good lightweigt rechargeable trimmer. Don't bring it anywhere near water, but still cleanable. I even use it on other...areas of my body with great results.<br /><br />EDIT: Had to knock it down a star for battery life. When you charge it, it definitely has enough juice to trim whatever you need to. But I've used it more infrequently as I shave more regularly, and when I do need to use it, I've noticed it has almost no charge after a few weeks in the closet.

Sturdy, curved to fit your hand just right, and the shape makes it easy to get into the corners of your face that might be hard to reach with some trimmers.<br />2) Charge last for a LONG LONG time. Longer than I remember my Norelco's lasting.<br />3) Does not have a bin for the cut hairs, but makes as much mess as my Norelco's did, which is to say, not that much.<br />4) Price at $14.77 is excellent.   579. When I got this trimmer I was enthusiastic. For as long as I had been trimming my beard I had mostly used another remimgton unit (small silver remimgton with several heads and a base that you can stick a charger through). My older trimmer would give me uneven cuts and wouldn't cut short enough. When I saw reviews for this, I figured I would give it a shot. After I charged the unit I was shocked to see that this guy trimmed my beard fantastically. Although, I still need to do some supplemental work around the beard line, this was easily the best trimmer I had ever used. However, there are two things about this model that I do not like: Cleanup and Battery. You cannot clean this unit with water, you have to brush loose hairs out or blow them out. This unit lets you flip open the blades to remove hairs that have accumulated under the blades. The problem is that under the blades resides a gunk that allows the components to move easily. I wasn't sure what to do- wipe off the gunk or blow away as much as possible. Whichever the case, the inside of the trimmer will always have stray hairs in it. My second and most important gripe is the battery. Mine can no longer hold a charge after only two months. I am not sure why you cannot plug and use this trimmer but it doesnt charge when the power is on. This is a problem I had with my older trimmer and a few others- why can't you charge and use? Overall, this was a good trimmer while it was able to keep a charge(2 months). I'm not sure what my options are. I know I can't return it to Amazon- maybe I can get a replacement battery.
  580. I was looking for a replacement for my old Philips Norelco T980 and happened on this. The T980 was overall a very good trimmer despite a few minor flaws. Considering how inexpensive the MB-200 is, you would expect to get a low quality trimmer with few features. Remington succeeded in making a very good trimmer that is devoid of several features of more expensive models, which is fine if you don't need that kind of stuff anyway. Pros: - Size is just right and it fits well in the hand. This may seem like kind of a strange criteria, but I thought the T980 was a bit large. The MB-200 is smaller and contours to the shape of your hand. - Wheel-clicks adjust the height of the clipper, meaning you don't have to change anything out for different heights. This is really convenient and the height of the clipper seems quite sturdy regardless of how high it is. There are also 9 different length settings. - Very easy to use and relatively quiet. Cons: - The hair. This can be quite messy - it lacks any sort of chamber or vacuum to catch stray hairs, so be prepared for a mess. - Long charge time. Overall, you can't complain for the price and the quality of the trimmer.
  581. Bought it for myself and then I got alopecia, a condition that makes all your hair fall out. Needless to say I do not need it now. Gave it to my brother. He ended up getting a job as an IT administrator for a very large company with a 6 figure income. My understanding of this product of this product is whoever buys it will loose all there hair. Whoever its gifted to will become rich. So make sure to put this on your Christmas Gift list!
  582. This unit is simply the best simple electric shaver out there for the price. My first one finally broke after several years of excellent use & I knew that I would just buy it again. My hair is a constantly evolving canvas, so I've gone through all sorts of facial hair styles over the years & this shaver can do them all. It's great for lining up & trimming beards, goatees & hairlines and can even handle simple hair cuts when in a pinch. It will even shave reasonably close to the skin if you don't need a super close shaven look. No electric trimmer is going to give you a shave as close as a plain ol' blade, but it works reasonably well for what it is & what I want. The adjustable height levels work well, the mechanism is long-term sturdy & the entire device is easy to clean. It holds charge well, so I never really have to worry about bringing the charger when travelling for less than a few weeks. Basically, it's awesome. Highly recommended.
  583. The product is warranted for two years. Two years and 9 days later the trimmer died. It is too inexpensive to return. Just be aware.

  598. My biggest problem with this trimmer is the battery / battery life. I'm on my second one now, and, I've owned the one I have now for right at one year on the nose (I purchased off Amazon May 2014. After about 6 months, the battery gets to where it won't hold a charge. If I plan on using this thing, I have to charge it all night long, then take it off the charger and IMMEDIATELY begin using it. If I take it off the charger, then, use the razor 10 minutes later, it's dead. The first one was like that too. The only reason I bought a second one is that I love how it trims with the guards. It's the only beard mustache trimmer I've owned that will get right up to my nose below my lip WITH the guard on. Others I've owned - the guard is too thick or something and it won't reach the hair between my upper lip and nose. I'm not sure yet if I'll buy a third one because of this battery garbage, but , well ... there you have it.

Since I play a distinguished gentleman, the beard had to be neatly trimmed. Rather than spend money on a barber or hair dresser, I decided to purchase an electric trimmer, which cost only as much as a single visit to a barber.   605. I owned the Remington MB-300 for a long time and loved it. When I needed to replace it, the MB-300 was nowhere to be found. Remington's site is confusing in that it advertises products you don't see at retailers and conversely it doesn't give information about products it makes that do exist at retailers. I found this model as a replacement, and except for being black, it is identical in appearance to the MB-300. The only difference I can tell between the two is that this one will not work unless the battery is charged (that is you cannot run it off of AC power). The problem with this is that the battery charge doesn't last long, and I frequently forget to plug it in, and it takes a long time to charge--so if you needed to trim before heading out the door and forgot to leave this plugged in, you're out of luck. I wrote Remington an e-mail with a suggestion that they bring back the MB-300 model back in October 2011, but they never responded. If I were buying one again, I would make sure the model works when plugged in.

I have to keep it plugged in all the time, which has become impossible since my wife got an electric toothbrush. It takes multiple hours to get enough of a charge for a full trim. My former review of this item was favorable, as I like the design and built in/removable length guide; but the inability of this device to run off a wall current is forcing me to buy a new device.

It takes about 20 minutes before it will have a single minute of charge. Also, the battery only seems to last me about 2 uses before it needs to be charged.<br /><br />Keep in mind that the battery used in this is a type that suffers from &#34;memory&#34; issues. If you just keep it plugged in all the time, the battery will quickly become unchargable, and since it can't work directly off the power adaptor--you will end up without a working trimmer.<br /><br />But all that is to be expected at this price point. All in all, I would buy it again. It's a no frills tool that does what it is meant to do, and does it well. There is no pulling feeling at all after years of using it.

The product description says that it's \\"corded/cordless\\" which isn't true. If the battery is dead you have to plug it in and wait for it to charge, you CAN'T use it off of AC power. I was usually able to get 1-2 trims per charge, and if you let it sit too long the battery drains. On the other hand, leaving it plugged in all the time also seems to kill the battery life, it will barely do 1 trim on a full charge these days. For the price though it's probably a good deal - I bought it 2 years ago and it finally bit the dust today, even after charging all night it can barely move the blades.

  659. For the price of $25.00 when I bought it, this is definitely a great product. I love that the trimmer can adjust to 9 different trimming lengths with just 1 comb instead of multiple attachments that takes time to replace, takes up space to pack and can possibly get lost.<br /><br />The trimmer claims to have self-sharpening blades but I haven't owned this product long enough to validate this claim.<br /><br />This trimmer is rechargeable through a provided AC adapter. It does come with its own LED charging indicator, however NOTE that the LED will only tell you that the unit is charging; it will not tell you when the charge is complete. The charging indicator is simply what it is, a light to tell you that the unit is indeed charging, that's it.<br /><br />The trimmer DOES run while it is being charged but I do not know if this means that it is indeed running while charging simultaneously. I will have to drain the battery one day and test this out for sure.<br /><br />As for the performance of the trimmer. It does what it's advertised to do. My beard is nicely trimmed. The unit is very sturdy since I do apply a fair amount of pressure when I trim and not once has the comb slipped down to its shorter length settings. I don't have very thick facial hair so therefore the trimmer cuts nicely. I do not know if it is powerful enough to handle people with very thick facial/body hair.<br /><br />It definitely does work as a body trimmer as well.

  668. The trimmer itself is well designed, easy to use, and effective. However, it uses outdated Ni-Cd battery technology that is prone to issues like memory effect. After about a year of use, I now have to charge it all day for about 2-3 min. of battery life (even though I have been using up the whole battery before recharging it). I would recommend instead purchasing a trimmer with a Ni-MH or Li-Ion to avoid this issue.

The trimmer is in perfect, like-new shape, and will probably last at least 10 years if I can figure out how to replace the batteries. Great product, shame they made this one lousy decision.

  675. Husband loves this particular trimmer. I looked in all stores for it and could not find. Then I said if it's available at all, Amazon will have it. There it was. Thanks
  676. This trimmer is very high quality, especially for the price, however even the first setting is too long for a short beard. I take off the attachment and go right to my skin with the buzzer, which is fine, but this thing is more of a head trimmer than a beard trimmer.
  677. Excellent trimmer, works very well on my sideburns and beard. Ive been using it for about a year now and the only downside ive ever seen is the battery charge wears down quite fast if you dont keep it plugged in.
  678. It's a shame we live in a world where gadgets and gimmicks rule supreme over quality and simplicity. This razor is as straight forward as it gets. Its blades are sharp and the guide is dependable. It looks like they had to drop the price dramatically; most likely due to the supreme need for more and more and more choices, instead of quality items. If you are looking for simplicity of design, ease of use, and quality of craftsmanship, then this is the best choice.

  689. speedy delivery, very good product!
  690. I should say that this replaced the model before the one I just purchased. The trimmer is very simple. It dials up and down for certain beard lengths. It also is designed to go with the direction of the growth of the hair. This almost makes it foolproof. It also is very good at blending the hair especially at the base of my neck. It is also ergonomically good and that's important if you are trimming your own hair. The charging of this unit is such that you can't overcharge it. I think I had the original version of this trimmer for 17 years and a few weeks ago it just wouldn't charge/run anymore. What this accomplishes is that your trimmer is always completely charged and cuts optimally. A lot of rechargeable trimmers require that you let them discharge and then you may have to recharge for 10 hours or more. Some call for not letting them discharge completely or it causes the batteries to wear out faster. The trimmer is very easy on the face when trimming your beard. You don't have to snap on and off the combs some models require for different beard lengths and this eliminates the possibility of breaking the combs. I've dropped these combs in the past and broken some of the teeth or the edge which holds the comb in place. To sum it up, simpler is better and I think I actually purchase this unit for less than the original one. It also has plenty of power. I paid $40 for a unit from a major brand name and it isn't half as powerful as this one. I was happy to see that Remington was still supplying this model.
  691. So the first MB-200 I bought had the batteries go bad in a little over 1 year. I thought maybe it was me or I just got a bad one. I did like the razor so I ordered another one. These batteries also went bad after 1 year. My wife's Panasonic razor is still going strong after 2 years.<br />I pulled the old razor apart and soldered in a pair of decent rechargeable AA batteries and these are still going strong. Remington uses a very poor rated battery which, obviously, does not last. This is my last Remington!!
  692. Prior to purchasing this trimmer, I owned the same rechargeable Remington beard/mustache trimmer for 10-years. I had no problems with it until the final year of its long and illustrious life. I purchased this MB-200 trimmer expecting the same positive experience. However, this trimmer only lasted one year and 5 disappointing months. After about 6-months, the rechargeable battery life began to decline rapidly. I had to charge it overnight and then use it immediately the next day. If I let it sit for even a day without charging, it would only work for 30-60 seconds before dying. That wasn't ideal for home use and it made it mostly worthless for travel, but I learned to live with it. Then more recently the gears that control the adjustable guide broke, making the device worthless for trimming one's beard at any given length - charged or not. I had to throw it out. I would add that I probably only used the trimmer 1-2 times per week, and sometimes not for a couple weeks at a time during its lifetime. I don't think it died from overuse. I will be purchasing another, better made brand for my next trimmer.
  693. Excellent purchasing experience! Very satisfied with both the shipping service and quality of product.
  694. Junk. Won't even hold a charge long enough to get thru a single trimming. And when the battery runs down, simply plugging in the charger provides insufficient juice to run it. Essentially, you need not only a fully charged battery, but it also must be plugged in. Forget traveling with it unless you want to bring the charger, too.

It rarely lasts more than 2 trims (I average 2 trims a week) and there is ZERO indication that you're running low. There is a small LED battery indicator, but it only serves to tell you that the unit is charging when it's plugged in... as if you didn't already know that.<br /><br />Also it cannot run off of wall power when plugged in, making it impossible to use if it has died. I have been using this trimmer for a few months now and I love it! Adjustment is very easy via a thumb wheel to trim at various lengths and the shape and weight of the unit makes it easy to manouver. The unit can be easily brushed clean or rinsed which is very convenient. I also like that the fact that the charger is not some clunky charging base that takes up my limited counter space, it is just a simple cord that plugs in to the base if the trimmer.   726. After unsuccessfully trying another brand (Wahl) beard trimmer I replaced it with this Remington. I should have known better as I had had a Remington for seven years and loved it! This trimmer is solidly built, not flimsy or &#34;plasticy&#34;. It feels good in the hand. The length guard, controlled by a number dial, stays where you put it for an even, neat trim. The stubble guards are plastic, but they are nice enough to held up for use and are the right lengths. No problem with it &#34;tugging&#34; on your beard. Easy to charge, although I wish it came with a charging stand. In an effort to keep this short... the bottom line is, for a bit more money than the inferior brand you can have a solid, precise, easy to use beard trimmer with many, many different trimming lengths to keep you looking your best with minimal effort. I would recommend this Remington for those guys with full beards that need trimming and o guys that want the three-day-growth look. It work great for both! Please remember, this is one person's opinion and YMMV,

  776. Before you purchase this beard trimmer, be aware of these two major flaws:<br /><br />1. It ONLY runs on battery power. Everyone nowadays is accustomed to using their laptop and cell phone, where you can take your device with a dead battery, plug it in, and begin using it right away with full power. With this beard trimmer, you can't just plug it in and use it-- the battery has to charge first. If your trimmer is new, that takes at least a few hours. As your device gets older, it takes longer and longer--it now takes me a full 24 hours to charge the battery to the point where I can get a full beard-trim out of it. And that brings me to flaw #2.<br /><br />2. The battery will stop holding a charge after a fairly short life. I used mine about once a week for about three years before it got really bad-- that's probably 100-150 charges of the battery. If you're someone using it every day, of course you would go through 100-150 charges much faster. As I mentioned, I now need to charge the trimmer for about 24 hours before I can use it. As soon as it gets unplugged, it will lose the entire charge within about 6 hours or so whether it is turned on or not. Thus, I have to plan my beard trimming 24 hours in advance, and for someone with a hectic life this can be very difficult. I don't think there's any way to swap out the battery for a new one--I have done some searching for solutions and have not found anything.<br /><br />If there was a way to swap out the battery for a new one I would do it, because I otherwise like this beard trimmer. I like the curved design, and I like the numbered length settings with the handy wheel. It has always cut quite well and never pulled my hair, except when the battery dies mid-shave (which now happens frequently). I did get a good three years of light use out of it, but I still think the product should be made better and should last longer. And I still think it's ridiculous that you can't just plug it in and use it.<br /><br />So: it's not without its merits, but overall I have been a little disappointed by this beard trimmer and I will definitely choose a different one as a replacement.
  777. Battery failed after a few months of use. Do not buy this crap shaver. I should have purchased something from Norelco and stayed away from Remington, but I did not listen to common sense that told me not to buy anything from Remington....EVER!!!
  778. I thought this was going to be an awesome beard trimmer because of all the good reviews and videos, boy was I WRONG!!! This is pure JUNK!!! First it doesn't work while being charged (plugged in). After 8 months I had to charge it 24 hours in advance of use because it die after 2/3 min while being used. The charge now only last less then a min and have to charge for 10-15 between uses. I would only use this unit once every 10 days to two weeks or so. Stay away, endless you like buying a new beard trimmer every year or so.

Instead, you need to charge the battery up first. This is rather annoying, especially because at this point the battery doesn't hold a charge for more than a couple days anymore. This means that anytime I am going to use it, I have to plug it up first, then come back the next day or many hours later and use it then. That's what I've been doing, and it works, but I feel like it's a problem. It should really work while plugged in, even with a dead battery. At this point I'd much rather have a trimmer with a permanent cord so I know that I can always use it when I need to. If that one flaw were fixed, this would be five stars all the way. But with that issue, I can't fully endorse it. Didn't crop up until about a year in, so I suspect they don't use very high quality rechargeable batteries.

Also, there is no good way of getting under your nose with this thing. The depth guard will be up your nostril before your hair even comes close to the trimming blade!

I've had the unit a couple of years, so perhaps it wasn't always this way, but it has had this problem for at least a year. The length adjustment mechanism is cheap plastic, the trimmer was dropped once and landed comb-end down, which broke something with the adjuster and now any length setting less than 7 will slide to 0 mid-trim which is a big problem. If I'm very careful not to push it too hard against my face, I can keep it on 7 or above.   808. I ordered this beard trimmer back in Feb 2012 and 19 months later it looks like I'll have to purchase a new one, since this Remington MB-200 is now officially dead. Specifically, the battery no longer holds a charge at all, and unfortunately you can't turn the trimmer on while it's plugged in. It's really a shame, because when I first got the trimmer it worked wonderfully. With a full charge it would easily cut through my beard, which is quite thick compared to most and grows rather quickly. That said, I probably got more use out of this trimmer than most men with thinner beards, and I'm sure the frequent use and recharging was responsible for the untimely death of the trimmer. However, I still find it ridiculous that I wasn't even able to get 2 years out of this trimmer, particularly when my Panasonic Electric Shaver has been alive and kicking for several years now, and is still going strong!<br /><br />Overall, these are the main reasons I would NOT recommend the Remington MB-200:<br /><br />1. Unable to trim while plugged in - There were times when I ran out of battery mid-shave. Rather than continue my day looking like the Batman villain Two-Face, I had to resort to shaving off my beard completely, instead of simply trimming it. It would have been nice to have been able to plug in the trimmer to continue the shave, but it doesn't work that way. Plugging it in is only for charging the battery--not trimming.<br />2. No low-battery indicator - Problem #1 listed above might have been lessened had there been some sort of battery indicator on the trimmer, but there is nothing. This means that you have to gauge the remaining life of the battery by the sound of the rapidly slowing blades. So if you hear the buzz of the blades start to struggle, you'd better finish up your trimming quickly or risk having a partially trimmed face. I'm not asking for anything fancy here. A nice &#34;percentage of battery power left&#34; icon would be nice, but even a flashing LED light would be helpful. ANYTHING! But no, there is no indicator whatsoever. Very frustrating.<br />3. Long charge time - Most times this wasn't a huge issue and charging overnight was the way to go. However, when I was left stranded with a partially-shaved face from problem #1 above, waiting 10+ hours for a good charge wasn't an option.<br />4. Horrible battery life - As I said, I wasn't even able to get 2 years out of this product and the battery no longer holds ANY charge. Even before its untimely death I could notice the number of trims I could squeeze in before requiring a recharge was quickly dwindling. Within the last month or two I could barely complete a single trim before needing to recharge.<br /><br />Fortunately, this wasn't an expensive purchase, but as outlined above, there were a few simple fixes that would have made this a much better product. When it was working it did its job well. But it was always a gamble, especially while traveling, wondering how long the trimmer would last before sputtering to a complete and unexpected stop.light would be helpful. ANYTHING! But no, there is no indicator whatsoever. Very frustrating.<br />3. Long charge time - Most times this wasn't a huge issue and charging overnight was the way to go. However, when I was left stranded with a partially-shaved face from problem #1 above, waiting 10+ hours for a good charge wasn't an option.<br />4. Horrible battery life - As I said, I wasn't even able to get 2 years out of this product and the battery no longer holds ANY charge. Even before its untimely death I could notice the number of trims I could squeeze in before requiring a recharge was quickly dwindling. Within the last month or two I could barely complete a single trim before needing to recharge.<br /><br />Fortunately, this wasn't an expensive purchase, but as outlined above, there were a few simple fixes that would have made this a much better product. When it was working it did its job well. But it was always a gamble, especially while traveling, wondering how long the trimmer would last before sputtering to a complete and unexpected stop.

Add to that the 4-8 hour charge time, and it never seems to be ready when you need it. You must remember the night before that you are going to use it the next morning, and plug it in. If you forget and plug it in the morning, hoping it will have enough of a charge to use before you leave the house, it will never happen.<br /><br />Another problem is the way it scatters hair everywhere. It covers the sink, the counter, everything after you use it. This was my first trimmer, so I thought this was just the nature of the beast.   818. This trimmer works great. Cuts smoothly with plenty of power. Easy to clean, lots of adjustments. It holds a charge for a long time and is a good size in your hand. As far as the trim, I haven't felt it tug or pull whiskers one time, and it has a wide range of lengths, from stubble to quite long for a trimmed beard.   824. Nobody ever told me this was a mustache and beard trimmer: I've been using it to buzz my scalp (and beard) for years. I've used it two to three times per week, every week, since the day I bought it. It's been around the world in my luggage. I took it to Thailand fully charged, and managed a full month of brisk use without charging it! It's cordless, so I can buzz my hair in the shower and just wash the mess down the drain. Over the years, it's taken a number of tumbles from counters and shelves. The paint is worn through in a few spots, and the tips of a few teeth on the hair guide have snapped off, but it's still very functional, and you can get a replacement hair guide from Remington for just a couple dollars. The only reason I give it four stars instead of five is that it would be nice if it had a recessed power switch, since it's switched itself on in my luggage and drained itself a few times. In the meantime, I put a piece of tape over the power switch before packing it away. I suppose another con is that the charger is 120V only, which can be a problem for international travel. There aren't a lot of products that I whole-heartedly recommend to friends, but this is one of them.

  830. I purchased this trimmer for the sake of removing the guide comb and trimming my beard to have a \\"shadow\\" remaining, and used the comb to maintain a sculpted chin with a setting of 3 or 4. This trimmer allows you to flip a wheel to increase or decrease the width between the guide comb and trimmer head. I went with the Remington MB-200 due to the cost and high star rating here on Amazon, and I was very let down. For starters, like mostly everything else made today, this thing is made with super low quality fragile plastic, in and out. The guide comb is extremely breakable and is made of the thinnest plastic. However, that was not my main issue. I used this trimmer only five times until it completely broke down. Remington used a cheap underpowered motor. In my specific case, the little rotating motor pin under the trimmer head simply died down the more the trimmer was activated (it was audibly struggling to the point where it sounded like a car whose transmission was about to die). Eventually it stopped working entirely, and it could no longer nudge the trimmer head anymore, even though it was fully charged. This experience made me realize that it might be better to simply choke up the $80+ to get a real trimmer, preferably a salon-quality one from a big name like Oster, with metallic guide combs. After all, this is something I'll be using every day for the rest of my life. I'm guessing these cheap items are assumed to die down in the short-run and therefore be \\"disposable.\\"

  832. First of all, since a lot of people are wondering...here is the sizes (listed from the manual) that each setting will trim: 1 : 1.5mm, 0.06\\" (Stubble look) 2 : 2.5mm, 0.1\\" 3 : 4mm, 0.16\\" (Short) 4 : 5.5mm, 0.22\\" 5 : 7mm, 0.28\\" (Medium) 6 : 9mm, 0.35\\" 7 : 11mm, 0.43\\" 8 : 14mm, 0.55\\" (Long) 9 : 18mm, 0.71\\" I'll admit, this is the first trimmer I've ever bought...but I think I made a great choice. I've had it around a month now, and trim on average twice a week. Everything about it is simple, easy to pick-up and use. - Cleaning is simple. It comes with a comb and brush to clean the trimmer. - I've read some reviews that say the plastic pieces are flimsy/break easily/etc. So far, I've had no problem. The guide is easy to remove (honestly though, just in case I'm totally baby-ing this thing so it won't break). - Some reviews say that even without the guide, it doesn't trim close enough for them. In my opinion, if that's not short enough for you...then you just need to shave! I use setting 1 to get a stubble look on my cheeks, a 3 for my mustache, and a 5 for my goatee. And I remove the guide to define the edges. Simple, and takes away a lot of the time used for shaving and cleanup. Overall, great product. Hoping it will last awhile -knocks on wood-, if not I guess I'll have to search for a more sturdy one or buy this one again lol.

  836. I was thrilled when I received this trimmer. It felt right in my hand and the blades were sharp and stayed sharp. The adjustable spacer stayed put where it was set, and I never had to worry about accidental changes in trimming length. I'd trim about once a week or sometimes two weeks. The problem was the trimmer did not hold charge very long, and the capacity seemed to be diminished as the unit aged. Having experienced with rechargeable devices with cheap rechargeable batteries, I decided to open it up to see if I could replace the batteries. I discovered that the batteries are permanently mounted and not replaceable, unless you want to do some work to disconnect the old batteries and solder 2 replacement AA-size batteries into place. Each of the original batteries is rated 600mA. Hence, this was a practically made to be a disposable trimmer. Its life probably is dependent on how often you use it and how you recharge it. Frankly, it is unfortunate that it was engineered to the thrown away before the blades become dull. UPDATE: The manufacturer was very responsive to my review/experience with my trimmer and it offered a solution. This great customer care/service earns the product another star in my review. I am definitely a fan. Having said that, my next trimmer will have replaceable parts, if such trimmer exists and works as well as this one. It would be nice if companies think about products that generate less waste. UPDATE #2: I am reducing my rating to 2-star because the brandnew replacement unit I received from Remington does not hold charge more than a few days. Customer service was great but a bad product is still is a bad product.

  838. Got this for the hubs for Christmas.... so far so good. He really likes it and says it works well.
  839. It's lightweight and works great.
  840. I've owned 3 of these now and they all last between 1-2 years before the batteries stop holding a charge. Of course Remington won't let you use the trimmer while it is plugged in, so you can't just use it as a corded trimmer. If you purchase one of these, just don't expect it to last any longer than 2 years, because it won't. The actual trimmer itself is pretty nice and is built well, the adjustments are easy and when the batteries hold a charge it works really well. If you are okay with something like this lasting you less than 2 years I would recommend it, otherwise I would recommend a corded trimmer or a different brand.
  841. I absolutely love my Remington MB-200 beard trimmer! This is my second one. Hope they never quit making this model. I highly recommend this trimmer to all you bearded guys out there!<br /><br />James Chowns
  842. I bought the older MB-200 model about 8 years ago. It could sit charged for two months and still give me 15mintues of operation.<br />I bought three of these newer units for myself and my nephews and we must always plug in the unit for a few hours before shaving. You get about 10 minutes of use after a fresh charge. If you let it sit for a month the charge reduces significantly.<br />When the batteries are dead, it is unusable for at least 1 hour until the batteries develop some charge.
  843. I followed proper charging procedure and got about 3 trims off the first charge. The next charge didn't last long enough to finish trimming my beard even once (less than 2 minutes). I thought it must have charged incorrectly and tried it again and it got worse. I tried a third time to make absolutely certain that I was charging it with the correct charger and procedure, and now it runs for less than 10 seconds after charging overnight. It's worse than useless because I depended on it and wound up with a half-trimmed beard. Thanks for making me look crazy, Remington.<br /><br />Unfortunately I use it so rarely that the window to return it is way closed. I just have to suck it up and eat the expense. This will be the last time I buy a NiCad device online.

  845. Does not hold a charge long at all. You need to continuosly keep in plugged in. After charging you can get 1-2 trims in. Very disappointed.
  846. I first bought one of these from my local Walmart a few years ago and absolutely loved it. When I moved, I lost the power cord for it so I couldn't charge mine anymore. This is such a nice trimmer that I could justify buying a new one just because I lost the old power cord.<br /><br />The built in length adjustment is awesome. When you first use it, start off long then slowly set it shorter until you reach a length you like and remember the number. I use 7 for my beard and 4 for my mustache.<br /><br />This lost a star due to a battery issue. If you leave it plugged in until you use it, it lasts long enough to cut your hair, beard, mustache, and to do a little trimming. But, my old one wouldn't keep a charge for longer than a day or 2, which means you always have to have it plugged in if you want to use it. I finished up the best I could on my face; however my thoughts were that this razor does such a good job of cutting that it accidentally cut itself. I put the razor away with a renewed respect.<br /><br />However, a few weeks later I needed to shave again. As I did so, another tine flew off to evermore decorate my bathroom floor. This made shaving increasingly more difficult. Every few weeks my beard was developing a strange look that I best defended as \\"trendy.\\"<br />I was going to call Remington and see if they could help, but I felt a little embarrassed as they could probably guess that I did something wrong with the razor. Not sure what I did, but Remington makes great products and they would never sell me something that is easily broken.<br /><br />In conclusion, people who do not have to shave their faces very often are really screwed over by 30 day guarantee programs.<br /><br />I ended up getting another electric razor, but I keep this one around out of respect. It sits on a little throne underneath my sink which is probably what it wanted all along.

The only con I can see is the top cover that is used for the adjustment is made of plastic.   942. Great trimmer! Does it's job efficiently and having the option of 9 different length settings is great.<br /><br />However, I do have a few gripes:<br />1) Battery Life. This thing will not last more than a single use per charge. You must always keep this thing plugged in when you are not using it. I would fully charge it, use it once, not charge it, then try and use it a second time on the same charge. It would die on me halfway through the trim and have me looking like a patchy half-shaved man. If you are okay with single charge single use, then this won't be a problem for you. But if you're like me and would not rather always keep a charger on your bathroom counter, then look elsewhere.<br />2) This is NOT a detailer! This device is used to trim all your beard hair to the same length for an even look all around. Even when you take the top off of the device, is provides an inadequate job of detailing your beard. You are better off using a simple razor to shape your beard.<br />3) Figuring out how to take the top off is more difficult than it should be. You must first turn the setting to the highest, 9, then pull it off-- for anyone wondering.<br /><br />Again, if these things aren't issues for you, then this is a FANTASTIC trimmer for the price. I'm still using mine in conjunction with my razor to have a clean looking beard everyday.
  943. This is the 2nd one I've owned. The 1st lasted several years until the battery would no longer hold a charge. It is so inexpensive & easy to use. Keeps your beard looking trimmed & neat with very little effort. No multiple attachments to deal with. Simple & effective.
  944. I've bought three of these things over the past few years (I dropped the first one and the battery died completely in the 2nd) and I'm never buying one again. The battery is horrific -- it takes a full day to completely charge, although there is no indicator of charging status whatsoever (only a green light to tell you it's taking a charge, but it never shuts off.) Leaving it unplugged for just 1-2 days and the battery gets almost completely depleted without ever turning it on. And the worst: IT DOESN'T RUN OFF A/C CURRENT WHILE PLUGGED IN. That's right, if your battery is dead you can't do squat with it, you have to leave it charging for a full day first. This thing is complete junk, avoid it!
  945. Bought this trimmer for my son who broke his while away at college. It fell off his dresser and crashed to the floor. It is the same trimmer that he had before and he really liked it. He's very happy with this trimmer and so he asked the same Remington trimmer if I could get one and I did. Amazon shipped it to his dorm quickly
  946. This item claims it doesn't pull your hair while shaving and that's all it did! I use these kind of trimmers to shave my facial hair and this thing kept pulling my hairs as I was attempting to shave my face. I returned it for a refund, but I just wanted to let people know that it does pull your hair. The description says it doesn't, but it does.
  947. Easy to use and holds a charge for well over a week. This is the first time I've really let my beard grow in and I couldn't be happier with how simple this makes it to keep myself looking presentable.
  948. Very poor battery life.This is what you get for such a price.In the future I would only go for a Panasonic even though they are a little expensive.

  950. I'vee had this product was the year, the battery has already died.I did exactly what the instructions told me to do, give it a big charge when I first got it.   953. I've had this for almost two years now and it's still going strong. The handle feels well-built and it doesn't show any signs of wearing out anytime soon. Overall it's a great razor. However, there are two things you should know about before buying it:<br /><br />(1) The razor only works off the battery and charges take a couple hours. I trim around once a week and I have to recharge the razor the night before. It won't work if you plug it into the wall with a dead battery.<br /><br />(2) The length scale is shorter than the standard barber units of 1 = 1/8 of an inch. This isn't really a big deal because you can just look at the plastic guard and see how far from the blade it is, but it took me a close shave to learn this. Maybe there are beard trimmer standards I don't know about though.

It keeps me looking as though I have 3 days growth on my face 7 days a week, which is exactly what I am going for.   990. I owned the initial version of this trimmer and absolutely LOVED it. The charge lasted forever and it's just a solid little trimmer that feels comfortable, gives you good, clean and even length settings and is very easy to clean. However, I dropped it once and the mechanism that snapped the top part on broke. My fault, so I was fine, but it was just too loose to be effective anymore. When they went on sale for $9.99 last year around this time, I was so excited ordered 5 of them, 2 for me and 3 as gifts. When I received them, I noticed they were a different color and in different boxing, but didn't think much of it since the design looked identical. Well, I have been using it over the last month after growing my beard back, and I am sorry to say that the newer version's battery is terrible. As other reviewers have said, it IS far worse than other trimmer battery lives, and the fact that you can't use it plugged in is a huge design flaw. Here's the problem: you start trimming your beard and the charge seems strong, but then in the middle it just poops out on you. Well, would be great if you could just plug in and finish the job, but no...you basically have to walk around with a half trimmed beard and hope the stupid thing charges fast. Don't get me wrong, the thing works great when it's fully charged...but if it doesn't hold a charge, that's a huge problem, because anyone who has a beard knows you aren't going to trim the thing every day. AND the fact that the initial version's battery held a charge forever tells me they cheaped out on the battery of the newer version, which completely destroys the integrity of what was a fantastic product. My old broken one still holds a charge forever, so I know this to be true. It's just a shame...
  991. I went through tons of reviews here about this product before I decided to buy it. Some raised the issue of the trimmer not being able to hold a charge or even work when plugged in. Since the overall rating of the trimmer was good (about 4.5 out of 5 stars) I ended up discounting these criticisms as flukes. I bought the trimmer and, for the first month or so it worked great. The trimmer itself is actually pretty good, which I think is the reason it has mostly positive reviews - most people reviewed it as soon as they got it, long before problems with the charge developed. But after a month or so it got progressively worse in holding a charge. Today, two and a half months after I bought it the thing not only barely holds a charge, now it won't even charge at all! Plugging it in now does nothing, rendering it absolutely useless. Unlike some of the reviewers who blamed the problem partially on their own poor maintenance (like leaving it plugged in constantly), I was careful not to leave it plugged in after it had finished charging. Even still, the thing only managed to last a couple of months. Its basically a disposable trimmer. Its just not worth it. Pay more and get a normal trimmer.

  1000. Is the trimmer of solid build? Yes. Is it more than capable of a nice even trim of a full beard (and then some) on a full charge? Yes. Does mine still trim as well as it did 18 months after purchasing it? Yes.<br /><br />So why the 3-star review? The first star (and I almost took off 2 for this alone) is because I was shipped a trimmer that had obviously sat on the shelves for a long time, which made my battery nearly DOA. Less than 3 months after purchasing it, the battery wouldn't last 5 minutes, so it was off to Batteries Plus to spend almost as much as I did on the trimmer just to replace the battery. That battery is still going strong, and based on other reviews, I expect it to go a while longer. The second star is for using soldered-in NiCad batteries instead of NiMH (free or soldered). I used free-standing NiMH batteries with the previous generation of this trimmer (which had a battery compartment instead of them being soldered-in) and they worked fantastically, so I have no doubt they would have worked well here. The charge times would be shorter and the run times would be longer, and the shaver would be much more eco-friendly. Because let's face it, are most people going to take their trimmer to a battery recycling facility or a Batteries Plus when their trimmer dies after 3 months? No, they're going to throw the trimmer, NiCad battery and all, in the trash, and buy another one for barely more than replacing the battery would have cost.

  1029. Initially, this thing works great. Holds a charge, does its job, etc. But after only 22 months the batteries no longer hold a charge for more than a few seconds. Nothing else is worn out and there's no way to replace the battery yourself. I think a ~$30 trimmer should last longer than that.
  1030. The ability to adjust the height of the cut and the ease of use makes this a must buy for those who like to keep their beards neatly trimmed.
  1031. This is a solid product. Beats my prior Norelco by miles. Holds a charge for over a week or more. The adjustable head holds its position something other products have a hard time with.
  1032. When it came time to finally replace my trusty old Norelco I was a bit leery of ordering something online, but the number of positive reviews and the fantastic price convinced me to purchase it. After serveral months I can say I am very pleased with this trimmer. It is solid and well built. It has very good battery life. It is comfortable to use and does a great job! I had thought of buying a more expensive model that would vacuum clippings, or one that would operate while plugged in (for those occasions where you forget to charge it) but hours of reading reviews left me concerned about complaints of poor performance and flimsy parts. I'm glad I saved myself some potential aggravation and money too! Shortly after getting this I recommended it to a friend, he ordered one and is also very pleased!
  1033. I like this trimmer better than my previous one because with this one all I have to do is rotate a dial to select the length of hair to be cut. With my old one, I had to change the covers to do that. To get the right length with the new one, I started with the highest setting and worked my way down. The trimmer could be a bit smaller, but it looks well built. If it is like the Remington shavers I've had, it should last a long time.
  1034. I purchased this because my Braun electric razor developed a problem with the power button: it wouldn't stay turned off. I got this for a quick, neaten-up while considering another razor purchase. I never made one; this does the job for me and cost so much less.<br /><br />For it's intended uses it works very well. But I use if for shaving. Here's how:<br /><br />Pull of the front, adjustable head and leave the bare cutting edge exposed. Drag that across your face. Not back and forth, just drag. WOW! It is fast and leaves just a stubble. That's just the way I wanted and it works fine for me.<br /><br />When new it held a charge for a long, long time. Now, with age, a full charge doesn't last quite as long. Nut, hey, it has a long life left in it still; and when it finally goes, I'll buy another one just like it. Thanks Amazon for a useful and efficient product!
  1035. I have recent decided to grow out my beard and need something to clean it up a little. This product was on sell for 15 bucks or something like that and already had great reviews. I have also used this to trim the hair over my 4 year old's ear in between hair cuts. The guard that is part of the unit doesn't slip off like other models i have used and I feel comfortable using it on my face and my sons hair. There are 9 levels that the trimmer can be set to as well. Great Product for someone looking to maintain a nice clean beard.
  1036. My first shaver was a 3 circular blade one. Only problem was it had no height settings and didn't cut the hair, only ripped it out of your skin.<br /><br />This shaver IS AWESOME. It has bunch of height settings with a height adjuster clipped onto it, and is easily taken off.<br /><br />I took it off and shaved my beard off in 30sec, and I have a HUGE beard. My old \\"shaver\\" took at least 5-10min to painfully remove the hair and clean the clogged up \\"blades\\".<br /><br />It can even be used to easily shave/trim \\"down there\\" or your arm pits.<br /><br />It won't get you baby smooth, but it will get you nice and shaven very quick. If you want baby smooth, just use a razor to finish the job.<br /><br />No batteries needed, it uses a plug just like a cellphone to keep it charged. It should stay charged for many shaves.<br /><br />My only con would be it doesn't have a stand, but I would buy this again in a heartbeat. Fantastic product!
  1037. This is a good no frills trimmer. It is inexpensive and does what it's supposed to. It gives a nice cut and has good maneuverability. I previously had a Norelco turbo vacuum trimmer which I loved which seemed to be quicker and the built in vacuum left significantly less mess behind too (so my wife liked it better too). If I had it to do again, I would probably get the Norelco just because the extra 5 minutes spent between the cut and cleanup can be a big difference in the morning (and with getting the kids ready in the morning... being done 5 minutes faster can be huge). But at ~$35 more, is that worth it to you? But honestly, the 2 products are 2 different price points and it is probably an unfair comparison. This does what is advertised to do and does it well.

  1042. I did a lot of research on Amazon before deciding to buy this trimmer. I bought this over a year ago, so I have had good time to review its effectiveness. Note that I have never owned a trimmer prior to this so I do not know what is common to all of them, or even unique for that matter, so I will just describe what I have liked (pros) and disliked (cons).<br /><br />Pros:<br />-cover protects face from sharp blades<br />-zoom wheel with numbered stops (incredibly useful)<br />-firm build<br />-cordless<br />-charge seems to last a good while<br />-cleaning brush included<br />-small comb included<br />-great price ($15 at the time)<br /><br />Cons:<br />-cannot use while charging (if you hear it dying out, and want to quickly connect the charger and use it, forget it. It needs time to charge, it's not a laptop in this regard. So, charge it every so often.)<br />-no charging base<br />-cannot stand on its own; can only lay down<br />-washable?!? I don't know. Amazon's bullet-point description says that it is not washable, but further down on the product page under product description, Remington has a table displaying four of their models and there is distinctly says that this model has washable design. I looked on Remington's website, but did not find anything that clarifies this. Well, I'm not taking any chances, so I'd avoid dunking this in water.<br /><br />I think this is a great trimmer. At the time of purchase, this product was $15. Now, it is $24.99. There are some other Remington models that are higher-end, or appear that way, and they are about the same as the current price. But, overall, I would say that this has been a great trimmer.

  1048. This thing has kept me and my beard happy for 8 years now. The only warning I would give is that the battery DOES NOT LAST when it is not hooked up to the wall. For instance, don't charge it and put it in your bag and expect to shave when you get to your hotel, it WILL be dead. The ONLY reason this thing is cordless is so that you can unplug it from the wall immediately before using it and then not have to fuss with the cord, and then plug it right back in afterwards. The battery is NOT so that you can haul it in your pack and shave on a mountain in Glacier National Park. This of course makes sense though, it takes a lot of power to get those blades moving and this design of battery is not the same as in your phone or laptop. This battery has to deliver a pretty high speed and lengthy amount of mechanical work, not just lights or computation. So I'm fine with the battery failing when it sits idle for a long time. The battery is only so you can shave without getting tangled in a cord, despite standing directly next to an outlet.
  1049. I don't have a full-beard, yet. But it will be here soon. In the mean time, I use this to keep the hair trimmed low, which keeps me from having to worry about my not-even-close beard from looking extremely hideous. The battery lasts forever and the trim levels actually lock on this product.

  1059. Product lives up to my expectations. I have a full beard and use the product to trim it at setting \\"3\\" (slightly longer than stubble). Excellent quality, especially given the price. The construction is solid and does not feel flimsy or fragile. The adjustable head has flexible \\"teeth\\" which look like it could break easily if handled roughly. But this is hardly an issue for its intended use. Very good battery life. I like the fact that the cutting blades are hinged and can be lifted and cleaned from underneath, no special tools required. Highly recommend.<br /><br />Update: Had to remove 1 star for the charger. I had to travel recently to a country where the outlet voltage is 220 volts, and realized that the charger is rated for only 110 volt AC input. This forced me to carry a (rather heavy) step down voltage adapter while traveling.
  1060. Best trimmer ever. Does exactly what I bought it for. I was looking for a very close trim because I don't always like using a razor.   1070. If you only plan to use it with the guard on, you're probably fine. If you plan to use it without the guard, especially for more intensive / multiple-angle tasks like head shaving, don't buy it. The top is designed so that if any significant pressure is placed on the blade when used in a pretty normal hand position, it can pop open. If it doesn't pop open, the plastic (!) pins in the hinge will break off. (The hinge is to allow you to open the top and clean out the hair around the driving pin.) I owned a prior model and it lasted for seven years of once-weekly head shavings with no guard, plus beard trimming. This version lasted barely six months before the first hinge pin broke, and less than a year before the second one broke, rendering the shaver unusable.

  1102. So, I got this because I wanted an all-in-one shaver that didn't have 30 stupid accessories for me to store/lose. After searching for a couple of days this fit the bill.<br /><br />The shortest setting isn't quite short enough for stubble, but it works.<br />The blade guard mechanism is still stiff after two years, which is an accomplishment. In most units these tend to fail rather quickly<br /><br />The only problem, and it's a big one:<br />The battery. After six months of use it stopped holding a charge for more than a day. Now, it holds a charge for about 15 minutes, but it runs at such a slow speed that it pulls, rather than cuts hair. IIt has the same amount of power that you'd imagine it to have seconds before death, a slow slow slow churning.<br /><br />So, the batteries have failed to deliver enough voltage to do anything, and now it's time for a replacement.<br /><br />Unfortunately this seems to be a theme among Remington products, their touch control razor (i went through 3, all returned) has similar battery issues within weeks. It's a shame because for another $5 per product they could source decent batteries and produce awesome products.

  1108. This thing is extremely easy to use. I especially like the fact that there aren't a dozen attachments that pop off easily. This thing holds a charge very well, is adjustable, easy to clean, and exactly what i needed.
  1109. Bought this for my boyfriend and he loves it. Works well, nice quality. Very nice job trimming his beard and the brush keeps it clean.
  1110. The product was exactly as advertised. It arrived within two business days at Christmas time! The price was almost half of a similar trimmer for sale by your competition.<br />I definitely will shop with you online again.
  1111. I haven't had this that long, but so far i enjoy it.<br /><br />This is essentially clippers, the same one you may get your hair cut with at a barber shop or hair salon. The extra feature is the adjustable length you can set it to. You simply roll the dial on the side of this device and it adjusts the measurement device at the end and you go to town.<br /><br />It's all pretty easy and convenient. It advertises that it auto sharpens and you don't need to oil it, which is great because I hate doing that stuff for something like this.<br /><br />If you want to keep your facial hair a certain length, this is absolutely a great start especially for the price.<br /><br />I haven't had any battery issues yet, but if i do I will surely update my review.
  1112. Purchased on: February 12, 2011 for $14.95 Lasted just under two years. Does not hold a decent charge. Died on January 9 2013. Feels cheap. Glad I only paid $14.95. Two stars for both of the years it made it.

  1119. I'm on my second one of this model now. The battery in my first one finally gave out after years of reliable use. It was the model with the porcelain blades. I used it to cut my hair and my beard. The second one developed a battery issue where it wouldn't hold a charge very long. I guess not every unit can be perfect. Otherwise that is the word I would use for this product. Compared to the other garbage beard trimmers I've tried this is about as good as it gets. Give it a try. If it has a weak battery like my second one had, luckily they aren't too expensive to replace. My first one more than made up for the second one's faulty battery in service time.<br /><br />BTW, I agree with the other reviewers who wish that the shaver could run off of the power cord and not require the battery to be charged. That being said its battery lasts a long time on a full charge when its a healthy battery. That would be just what this model needs to perfect it. It would probably hurt Remington's business making that change. Everyone would only buy one but they would use it for decades and pass it onto their children. :-)
  1120. I already had one of these but it started not holding a charge. Surprisingly the new one doesn't hold more than about 5 minutes total run time. No stand to charge in, only a little plug in transformer with a cord. Won't buy again

  1129. I used it to trim my goatee 1-2 times a week. I charged it once in December 2012 and the charge lasted into June on that one charge, which was amazing! I took it on a trip and it died.   1130. excellent product. timely delivery.
  1131. The battery won't hold a charge past a year and a half. Form factor and the trimmer work great, but a complete waste of money because of the battery. Wouldn't be such a waste if you could simply plug it in and use it, but you can't even do that. It will only run after being charged, not while charging. UPDATE: Remington customer service reached out and after validating my purchase, mailed me a replacement device which arrived today (10/30/2014). It's great to see them stand by their product and replace devices like this (note that there is a 2-year warranty on these units). While the support is great, I'm leaving my original review intact since the type of battery used in the device, Nickel-Cadmium, does not appear to have changed which means it will also likely die in after a year and a half of use. Maybe my first device was a from a bad batch (not likely after seeing the other reviews), but in general Nickel-Cadmium batteries don't have as good a shelf-life as Lithium-Ion batteries. If this model were updated with a Lithium-Ion battery it would be a no-brainer purchase and recommendation, even if it added $20 to the cost. Again, great to see them stand by their warranty and replace a bad battery. I'll try and remember to update this review a few months down the road to share how this battery holds up.
  1132. Good trimmer, but the battery is awful. I have to recharge it after every other use.
  1133. So so. They should loose the light it eats power and i know where my nose is. Don't need a light to find it.
  1134. Do not buy this garbage. I am so frustrated I have taken the time to come here and leave my review.<br /><br />The batteries barely have a 1 year life and you cant use it while plugged in. I have opened it to see if I could change the batteries myself only to find out that they soldered them. Lol, two 1.2v NiCd AA batteries, that is 1999 technology and they are low quality.<br /><br />Definitely NOT buying from Remington again.
  1135. I'm really torn as to how to rate this. It trims very, very well. Really good job at that. However: the head (blades) attachment is a little flimsy and can pop off when you go to clean it. But the big problem is the battery, which would seem to be ni-cad. It loses its charge while not in use, it loses its capacity as time goes on, and it doesn't have that many charge/discharge cycles before it basically doesn't hold a charge at all. And, since it doesn't work while plugged in, it's useless until it's recharged. Which it doesn't do all that quickly either. So it's a great trimmer with some serious flaws. The built-in guard is great; no more rooting around in a drawer looking for attachments. The only think I don't like about it, as a beard trimmer, is the handle shape. It has a weird bend that makes it awkward to hold in some positions (mostly when doing my neck, but also the offhand side of my face). Don't think about using it for anything else, though. The blade is too wide to trim your mustache. Or your ears. I tried several times to use it without the guard, always with bloody results. I'm getting the smaller Wahl to use in conjunction with this. Neither one is perfect, but together they cover my needs pretty well.

  1176. I got this to replace another Remington that I had, which died after about 2 years' worth of use, and I'm writing this review after using it twice.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- The length guard is softer material and doesn't dig into your skin like the hard plastic ones<br />- The cutting head is larger than I expected, so it takes fewer swipes to do the job<br />- The design of the length guard should help keep things more even than the snap-on style length guards<br />- The length guard can be adjusted very easily, which is handy<br /><br />Cons:<br />- The trimmer as a whole is bigger than my old one, so detail work is a little challenging<br />- Removing the length guard to edge my goatee isn't as easy as it was with the other model<br /><br />Also, a #3 setting on this one is shorter than the #3 on my old one.
