  1182. I've had one of these for 2 years now and it has not given me any problems. I use the trimmer on its lowest setting to quickly shave off enough stubble to be considered clean-enough for work. The battery holds a charge for an impressive amount of time; I've been surprised to be able to shave without charging after not using the trimmer for a month. If I had to complain at all about the product I would say that, when it is getting low on battery, it starts to wind down and you can feel it losing power. This has become worse as the trimmer has aged. It's not much of an inconvenience though. Just plug it back in for at least 30-45 minutes and you should be able to get through a single shave. Bottom line: For the price, this trimmer would be hard to beat.
  1183. I am not sure why Remington and other companies find it so hard to make a good shaver. This model feels cheap and plasticky and it acts like one.   1189. I bought this Remington MB-200 type A beard trimmer a few years ago. When exactly I can't say other than it was at least 3 years ago, but not more than 7. After a couple of years I found that it wouldn't hold a charge the way it used to. I keep it in my shower and mainly use it to trim my goatee to a shorter length. In the last few months it hasn't held a charge well at all, requiring me to leave it on the charging cable by the sink.<br /><br />I decided to see if I could disassemble it and replace the battery. I found 2 interesting things - first, this uses standard AA Nickel Cadmium batteries (N-600AAK Sanyo Batteries which cost $2-3ea.). They appear to be easily replaceable. But I also found that disassembling this pretty much destroys it. While you might do a better job than I did, I found I had to remove the glued on side plates and pry the thing apart after removing the small screws that hold it together. You might do a better job than I did, but once apart I decided I was better off buying a new one. I removed the batteries to dispose of separately and properly and am ordering a new one of the same model.<br /><br />Cheap enough for the life it lasted, not user serviceable, dispose of properly due to battery type.
  1190. Been through a dozen horrible to average trimmers and wasted hundreds of dollars on them. This trimmer is solid, feels good in the hand and works exactly as you would hope. Dont buy anything else.
  1191. Battery does not hold a charge well and it will not operate without a charged battery. Older models would operate when plugged in, even if the battery was dead. Clearly quality has gone down. Also this model is more difficult to clean out hair caught under cutters.
  1192. So many of you have expressed their affection for the Remington MB-50.<br /><br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001JI6B5K/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_0<br /><br />I've had several of these type of trimmers, all at a wide variation in prices over the years. The Remington MB-50 was my favorite of all of them and also one of the least expensive. I used it regularly for about 10 years! I even used it occasionally to give my little Yorkshire dog a cut and trim. I never had a pulled hair while using it. It's hard to believe the Ni-Cad battery service life was that long!<br /><br />So when the battery recently no longer took a charge I did a lot of research to try to find another Remington MB-50 and couldn't find it any where. I was willing to pay any price for it just because I knew it was a quality product and liked the results.<br /><br />I halfheartedly ordered the Remington MB-200 http://www.amazon.com/Remington-MB-200-Titanium-Mustache-Trimmer/dp/B0009OMU0A/ref=cm_cd_ql_qh_dp_t<br /><br />Much to my surprise, the Remington MB-200 looks identical to my old Remington MB-50, with the exception of the new color. I've also noticed the motor sounds quieter than my original MB-50 trimmer, but perhaps that is because the MB-50 is now 10 years old.<br /><br />So if you're looking to replace your old Remington MB-50, give the Remington MB-200 a try. It doesn't have one of the new Lithium batteries that are all the rage today but if this Ni-Cad battery in the MB-200 performs anything like the old one did in the MB-50, you will never miss having a Lithium battery.
  1193. I've now purchased 4 of these over the last few years for various friends and relatives. I don't think you'll find a better beard trimmer for the price. I highly recommend this if you are a frequent trimmer.
  1194. Had an older model for like 6 years and when the battery finally died I couldn't find a comparable product. Instead I bought a more expensive Braun and have spent the last several months shaving for an excessively long time in order to evenly cover all areas of my face & neck. Just used this new model for the first time and it worked just like I remembered.
  1195. Though not as exacting as a Wahl hair trimmer, it is easy to use, easy to calibrate, easy to store and it gets the job done.
  1196. Well-designed beard trimmer. Adjusting the various lengths is really smooth and easy and its really easy to clean. The clipper on the end pops off and gives you the raw clippers for your sideburns and mustache.
  1197. Unfortunately, this stopped working after about 6 months. Not very sturdy and we ended up buying a replacement on-the-ground so we could see how well-made/sturdy it was.
  1198. For years now, I've been looking for a product to replace my old Norelco trimmers. They were awesome until Philips took them over and made them crappy. I still haven't found anything as good for the price, but this is the closest I've come. I liked it enough that I bought a second one, same model.<br /><br />Most importantly, it trims well without catching and pulling my hair. It has a decent number of adjustable lengths (9 settings), and it stays locked in place while trimming. It has a nice shape, which makes it comfortable to hold and easy to move around without accidentally adjusting the length setting or hitting the power switch.<br /><br />My first crticism is that you have to be careful with the battery. Of course, it holds a lot of charge when new, but it will diminish significantly if you're not careful. Despite what the directions say, my recommendation is to charge it fully, unplug it, and not plug in again until the charge is almost drained. If you don't charge the battery fully or begin charging when the battery is not close to empty, it will definitely reduce the battery life. Using care when charging will extend the life of the product. It would also be nice if you could trim while simultaneously charging, but this trimmer doesn't work that way.<br /><br />My second criticism is that the charger is only compatible with 120 VAC input. I often travel overseas, and this is the ONLY electronic product I have that is NOT compatible with inputs up to 240 VAC. It's the 21st century, why is this charger using a 19th century limitation in its power transformer?<br /><br />Overall, it's a good value for what I paid. My first one lasted about 21 months. I'm hoping to stretch this one beyond 2 years by taking more care with charging.

  1229. Bought this to replace a Norelco Accutrol 900 that I had for a couple years. The new Remington trimmer works great and the length adjustment stays were you put it.<br />As a warning - the operating instructions say to hold the trimmer so that the length adjustment wheel is facing away from you. This is INCORRECT because if you do that the blades are the same distance from the guide no matter what setting you have and the only thing that changes the depth of cut is the angle you hold the trimmer to your face! Hold it so the adjustment wheel faces towards you!!<br />I think most people would spot this right away but in case you haven't used a trimmer like this before, it's good to know before you make a mistake that'll last a week, lol.<br /><br />Had it for about a month now and it does a great job, still haven't had to recharge it since the initial charge. The only downside compared to my previous Norelco is that this one doesn't have a smaller pop-up detail trimmer...overall no big deal and I would highly recommend the MB-200 to anyone looking for a good beard & mustache trimmer.

The number gauge on all such units doesn't really mean much, and the same number between different brands and makes may not cut at the same length.

The instructions say to keep it charged and then let it run down completely and recharge every six months. The battery is not replaceable, so I'm hoping this one lasts much longer. As for the quality and features, it's top notch. Nine cutting depth settings, a removable guide, and pop-open cleaning are nice features, and the blades are very sharp and do an excellent job of cutting.   1259. I was wondering exactly how long I had been using this same trimmer, so I checked my Amazon order history. I bought it in September 2011! Now, 3.5 years later, it is still going strong. Other people have said theirs have died, so maybe mine is a fluke? Either way, I'm not complaining.<br /><br />It has 9 length settings (from 1.5mm / 0.06&#34; up to 18mm / 0.71&#34;), and the little click wheel makes it easy to change from one to the other. I actually have a second, smaller trimmer that I use for getting to places that I want completely clean-shaven, like my neck or under my jawline. This one is just good for trimming big patches at once.<br /><br />Cleaning is easy. You don't wash it, you just wipe it down with a cloth or soft brush. The blades never need to be sharpened or oiled either.<br /><br />What I don't like:<br />- The battery self-discharges. This means if you leave your trimmer unplugged for any significant length of time (more than about a day), the battery loses its charge. It then takes a really long time to recharge. I just leave my trimmer plugged in in a corner of the room at all times so that I don't worry about it not being charged when I need it<br />- If the battery is dead, you cannot operate the trimmer by plugging it in. This is not how things should work. If your cell phone battery dies, you can plug your phone in and turn it on as long as it's connected to the power outlet. With the trimmer, you have to wait until the battery recharges, then use battery power. And the battery takes a LONG time to recharge (more than a couple hours)<br /><br />Also, some people like trimmers that can stand up. This one cannot stand, but must lie flat. It's not a problem for me, but it might be for you.<br /><br />All in all, this trimmer is ideal for me, and it might work for you too if you're not bothered by the battery issues.

  1286. Great all in one trimmer without the need of changing the heads of the razor
  1287. This works great at first. After a couple months the batteries will not hold a charge. The only way I can use it is to let it charge overnight. Then take it straight off the charger to my face. It will not operate off the wall power. Any time in a drawer and you get 30 seconds of use out of it and a really funny looking beard. Once that happens even letting it charge a couple hours will get you another 30 seconds. I went back to using my Wahl hair clippers for my beard. I don't recommend this to anyone.
  1288. Does NOT work when plugged in when it has little to no charge. You need a trim because you notice it NOW. So you pull the trimmer out after a few weeks of not needing a trim and no charge and doesn't work when plugged in. So you go out scruffy leaving it plugged in for hours so you can use it later. Come on. Switch the wires so it will work as it charges and not just work off the charger. Parallel wiring would solve this problem .Otherwise, works great, easy to use, and fully adjustable. I will NOT BUY another trimmer that has this flaw. Thank goodness my electric shaver doesn't behave like this.
  1289. Cheap, efficient, and compact.
  1290. Worked well for the first year or so but now it doesn't hold a charge beyond a few seconds. When it works, it works pretty well but obviously not being able to hold a charge (plus you can't shave with it plugged in) makes it completely ineffective.

  1294. i used this product 3times and it's already not working. im not sure what's wrong with it. the charging light lights up green when plugged in, but it only tries to turn on for a few moments and fizzles out whether it is plugged in or not. it never got wet. the gaurd/comb is very cheap/flimsy and felt like it would break easily in the near future supposing i were to get more use out of it. the guard didnt lock into place very well and screwed up my beard the first time i used it. all in all, i was extremely disappointed due to all the positive reviews and ratings. but, at least it was a small price to pay to find out i probably need to drop a chunk of change on a trimmer to get decent results. i recommend this product to thrifty people who are used to being very careful to take care of cheap products and dont mind cheap, slightly unsatisfactory results

  1297.   1339. I have had a beard since I was 19. I have a skin condition and shaving breaks me out something terrible. Also I hate shaving, it's not natural for a man to scrap off all his facial hair on a regular basis. Thus many years ago I recieved as a gift a Remington beard trimmer. I loved it right out of the box.<br /><br />Beard trimmers have to be the best invention of the 20th/21st century. Now a man can have a beard but keep it tight. Thanks to beard trimmers most men now in America sport some sort of facial hair.<br /><br />My first Remington performed great, was built of a sturdy composit material and stayed relatively sharp. My biggest complaint with it was after about 3 years, the battery life died on it. It would not hold a charge. I would charge it for 3 hours and if I was lucky it may last 20 minutes.<br /><br />Thus I ordered myself the Remington MB-200 Titanium Mustache and Beard Trimmer off Amazon and can say so far I have no real complaints.<br /><br />The design of this newer model is almost exactly the same to my old one. So if you are a die hard Remington fan you will not have to go through any re-ajusting.<br /><br />It cuts good, the blades are sharp and lubricated well. NOTE, never run water under the shaver head to clean it, this washes away the lubricent. This model has the same beard height \\"wheel\\" you turn with your knumb to ajust cutting height.<br /><br />The battery life is great so far. I probably could trim my beard charging only every other time if I wanted too. The old shaver I had used Nichol-Cadium batteries. I am not sure if the newer model uses this outdated type or if they have switched to lithium. Either way, know that overcharging your shaver which I am prone to do at times, damages batteries. That may have been why my older model died on me.<br /><br />My only other complaint is the plastic on this new model feels a little bit \\"cheap\\". I get the feeling that if I dropped it, (like I did with my old model never resulting in breakage), this new model would break. So I guess I'll need to be careful and not drop it.<br /><br />---To buy or not to buy?---<br /><br />This is a solid buy, if the price it right. I only paid around 14.99 for mine off Amazon. They're going for more right now. Wait around for a price reduction and I am sure you can get this great trimmer for a great price.<br /><br />---Final thought---<br /><br />If you are looking for a good way to clean out the trimmer head when it gets clogged with hair, pop up the top and go outside and blast it with a few shots of canned compressed air. Best way I've found to clean it, that little brush they give you just doesn't cut it sometimes.<br /><br />Well good luck and remember a well grommed man is a successful man.<br /><br />And as always sorry for any misspellings and grammer errors. I went to public school, where my principal looked like Grizzly Adams and my teachers would reminisce out loud about the old days, when they could have beaten us when we were bad.ing in breakage), this new model would break. So I guess I'll need to be careful and not drop it.<br /><br />---To buy or not to buy?---<br /><br />This is a solid buy, if the price it right. I only paid around 14.99 for mine off Amazon. They're going for more right now. Wait around for a price reduction and I am sure you can get this great trimmer for a great price.<br /><br />---Final thought---<br /><br />If you are looking for a good way to clean out the trimmer head when it gets clogged with hair, pop up the top and go outside and blast it with a few shots of canned compressed air. If not, there is always that 2 year warranty Lol.<br /><br />Final Thoughts:<br />Overall I'm happy with my purchase. It does exactly as its advertised (except for the water thing, NEVER PUT WATER ON IT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! it comes with SELF SHARPENING BLADE and a CLEANING BRUSH! If you put water on it, it will ruin it!) and gets the job done fairly well for its pricing. The only con is it does NOT do Tape Ups for a hair line like I hoped it would, but thats my own foolish assumptions. Any way if you would like to keep your bear/moostachio in mint condition this does the job well with no nicking and cutting, a smooth cut, and a strong battery! I recomend it 4/5 stars!

  1361. I used this for both my beard and my hair and it was great for a year and a half. The only down side when it was working is that it took a while to fully charge (it doesn't run while plugged in like some more expensive models). The guide is firm and sturdy, I never had a single mishap or issue and the blades remained sharp the whole time I used it. It lasted about a 1.5 years of weekly beard and hair trimming - which would translate to probably 3 years of just beard trims - honestly pretty good for the price. It's not a &#34;top end&#34; trimmer, but it is a good deal and it's a reliable as long as the battery is alive.
  1362. perfect for my husband's face and also for my son's hair when I cut it at home to trim it up
  1363. Small size, easy to carry, easy to handle, easy to use and easy to clean, what else can I say, it works fine, battery last long.
  1364. I bought this product as a gift. It came highly recommended. The receiver is very pleased and now looks ever so handsome.<br />Thanks.
  1365. (IMPORTANT NOTES: I use only setting \\"1\\" - I prefer a `scruff' look and generally do not grow a full beard, so please keep this in mind when reading my review. I have not used any of the longer settings)<br /><br />My review will consist of 3 parts - first, a review of the Remington's performance and, second, some tips & tricks I have figured out when using the Remington. Lastly, some final thoughts / comments.<br /><br />PERFORMANCE<br />I have owned the Remington for about 3 months now and am generally pleased with its performance. The product is 100% analog - there are no digital displays and the length is adjusted via manual \\"zoom wheel.\\" Some trimmers indicate length via a digital display screen.<br /><br />The trimmer has a total of 9 length settings. It can go as low as 1.5mm (that's the setting I use 100% of the time) and as long as 18mm (setting # 9). The zoom wheel is placed exactly where I happen to place my thumb during shaving. This hasn't presented much of a problem, at least not for me - but I can see where it might for some people. On setting 1 (1.5mm), the trimmer will give a *slightly* longer than 5-o'clock shadow look - more of a `scruff' look (if that makes sense), but it's pretty darn short (the way I like it). I tend to press the unit pretty firmly against my face on some parts. The guide comb seems to do an admirable job of preventing nicks / scrapes / and cuts - I have not experienced any problems of the sort.<br /><br />The unit itself is fairly ergonomic and easy to hold. It feels like a natural extension of my hand and fits snugly in my palm - almost like a fork or a spoon. I do not have any issues with the unit slipping in undesired positions, etc.<br /><br />The blade area is approximately 1.5 inches wide - which seems to be `just right.' (see my picture) It's not too narrow, and not too wide. It seems to hug my face accurately and efficiently trims facial hair. I have a fairly chiseled face - not sure if that matters.<br /><br />The length guide comb is removable - you simply just need to yank it off (see my picture). This serves two purposes. First, it enables the user to use the unit to trim facial `borders' at the edge of one's beard. Personally, I just stick to my foil shaver for that, so I cannot comment on how well the Remington might perform (never have used that feature). Secondly, the blades themselves can be flipped open to enable cleaning inside the trimmer's cavity where some hair might collect over time (see my picture).<br /><br />The unit comes with a standard plug-in wall charger and a cleaning brush. During charging, a green light remains lit. Unfortunately, the unit does not indicate remaining battery life. This would have been a nice feature, though really it is a minor gripe on my end. Some have complained about the unit's lack of battery life. For me this has not been an issue. I seem to be able to use the trimmer for several shavings before charging becomes an issue. As well, 100% of my shaving is done in my home and so it's just as easy for me to charge the unit - I do not travel with it. I don't necessarily disagree with other reviews that complain about battery life - it just hasn't been a problem for me.<br /><br />It also would have been nice to have some sort of cloth carrying pouch for the trimmer. In all fairness, most of these trimmers seem not to include this - so it's not a deal breaker in my book.<br /><br />TIPS & TRICKS<br />Like any type of facial hair trimming product, your face will take time, perhaps several weeks, to `adjust' to the shaver's surface area. This is a known fact among the industry and, in fact, many regular / foil shavers will indicate this in the product's user guide.<br /><br />As far as usage, you may need to use a variety of angles and techniques on different parts of your face whilst trimming your facial hair. For me, on some parts of my face, I trim against the direction of the facial hair (left-hand side ofmy face), but on my right-hand side, I tend to use a combination of a `swirling' motion to trim my hair along with cutting crosswise. On my chin, I tend to use a quick, firm, and repeated upward motion. For whatever reason, these all seem to work well. I figured out these methods after having the trimmer for a few weeks and just seemed to fall into place over time. If you look closely, you will see that the hair on your face does not grow uniformly - some parts grow in different directions than other parts of your face.<br /><br />For those who prefer to maintain the scruff appearance, you will definitely need to trim your face more than once a day. I do so twice - once in the morning before work, and also shortly before I go to bed. I suppose this is not unique to the Remington, but just a general observation.<br /><br />FINAL THOUGHTS / COMMENTS<br />Generally speaking, I am satisfied with the product. I do not see myself running out and buying another brand - this one more than suffices. The unit is simple and 100% analog (to me that is a plus). Electronic components can wear over time or simply malfunction. I guess I tend to be a bit more `old school' in that regard (but feel free to disagree). The price point is also very affordable.
  1366. My husband used this trimmer for years before his went out. He was so disappointed that he couldn't find another in store, and was thrilled when we found it online. He loves it! He has very thick, coarse facial hair and is extremely particular.
  1367. I now own two of these - not because one broke, but because I left one at home while going on vacation and couldn't live without it. A lot can be said about a trimmer that works well and is inexpensive enough to order an additional one without hesitation. The only addition I would make to it is the use of a lithium battery and smart charger.<br /><br />A solid buy you won't regret.

According to the manual, you must not rinse the cutter assembly under water.<br /><br />But once you charge it up, and keep it clean with the enclosed brush, it does an okay job of trimming.

I went with it but it was still annoying.<br /><br />After maybe 50-70 uses it now won't keep a charge. I'm glad to finally have a reason to get something better.

  1382. I just ordered a replacement as my original which I had for 4 years, got damaged. I wear a meticulously-ssculpted, low-cut beard (about 3/8&#34; tapered) and these clippers with the click-roller adjustable wheel have been excellent at keeping me groomed. I usually use Setting 4 for through my beard and Setting 2 thru 3 to effortlessly blend my sideburns. They are chargeable (which is a HUGE plus) and I usually slip them into a thick sport sock when travelling and that works well especially since the blade is not exposed.<br /><br />One minus:<br />The original clippers had a small half-inch wide, flick-out blade for small detail grooming which was exacting for corners, ears, eyebrows and other 'just a smidgin' work. I was taken aback and disappointed to find that this feature has been completely removed. I guess I'll get used to the mold of plastic they put in its place.<br /><br />The overall quality of this item though makes it a keeper and my beard has an ever-expanding fan club...lol!
  1383. Smooth and comfortable adjusts from stubble to long with a thumb dial. Not a bunch of cheap plastic parts to keep track of. Nice.

  1386. The trimmer is ok.. convenient dial for various lengths without attachments.... removable guard for stubble look..   1391. The trimmer works well and the clip attachment does as well. The reason I gave it 2 stars is because something is wrong with the power system. So if I plug it in and start using it, it'll be maybe a minute before it slows and then stops working altogether -- EVEN WHEN PLUGGED IN. It's either a major design flaw or just a defect in my particular one.<br /><br />So, in order to use it, I have to first leave it plugged in for hours so it gains enough juice to get me through the trim session (during which I still have to leave it plugged in). I use it very sparingly so I haven't bothered to contact the seller or get a new one, but a more regular user wouldn't be able to get by with this issue.
  1392. I bought my first Remington Beard Groomer about 4 years ago and I was very satisfied with it. I did the initial charge as per the instructions, but the new groomer needs re-charging after only 1 trim (maybe 3 minutes in running time). Don't buy this product. I'm back to using my old groomer and when it fails, I plan to buy another brand, probably a more expensive model. The Remington is an inexpensive product and you often get what you pay for.

  1406. This trimmer charges quickly (in about 4 hours), works over a week on a charge. Great trimming performance, trimmer comb has positive stops (won't move unintentionally under pressure). Ergonomic design, very easy to hold - and to hold at the correct angle. The product information states that the cutting blade never dulls - thus far I agree (after over a year of almost daily use). Easy to clean. Fairly solid construction, quality materials. I would prefer some kind of indicator for the remaining charge level, since it just goes from normal cutting speed to near stall in seconds (that is a feature of the battery technology used). The charger is small and light weight, easy to pack or travel.
  1407. My old trimmer finaly broke, so I decided to give the Remington a try. The dial beard settings are solid, my old trimmer would move and change the level. I've been using it for several weeks and still have not had to recharge it. My beard has never looked better.
  1408. My beard does not grow very fast, but I like to keep it short so I do trim at least twice per week and each time takes less than two minutes. I originally bought this a few years ago and really like the design. The other beard trimmers had snap-on plastic blade guards that were so flimsy that they'd break against my face. With no blade guard, they were instantly useless. The Remington blade guard is made of heavy plastic that wraps around the entire trimmer and after several years has never broken.<br /><br />Since I use the trimmer infrequently, I do an overnight charge perhaps once per month and then the trimmer sits unplugged for up to one month without needing to be recharged. The trimmer does not come with any sort of stand, but I found that the trimmers that had stands were all of poor quality (like the two earlier ones that had a nice stand to hold broken blade guards that can neither be replaced nor repaired). The Remington is self-contained. What you see in the graphic is all that it is, except for the plug-in charger. The blade guard slides up and down via a scroll wheel and clicks at various, measured stops. Since there are no parts to keep track of, a stand really is not needed. I keep the charger cord in the vanity and pull it out when needed.<br /><br />When mine died, I shopped for a new one and could only find lousy trimmers at higher prices. One trimmer from Phillips came wrapped with a set of ear phones (whah???) and I quickly returned that to the store because the shortest setting of that blade guard was already longer than my beard. The Remington settings trim my beard neatly, but also allow trimming all the way down to &#34;heavy five o'clock shadow&#34;. I was pleased that somehow I could get overnight free shipping on this from Amazon.<br /><br />Ironically, I was able to get my old Remington trimmer (just like this one) to work simply by giving it another overnight on the charger. Maybe I didn't plug it in right ... dunno ... but the next day it was fine again and the replacement for it was waiting on my porch. This is a nice enough trimmer that if the batteries really did fail, I would take this apart and attempt to rebuild the battery pack by hand. Most likely though, if the internal battery pack really is dead, then the trimmer is so old that every other aspect of it is also worn out. At that point, I'll just reach for the one I just bought which is waiting in the package in the cabinet.
  1409. I've used it about 10 times, works great. Trims very close. Has meet all my expectations. I would recomend it.

  1443. Works well but needs to be charged often.
  1444. Battery won't hold a charge anymore. Just barely a year old. I think I'll get one with an easily replaced battery next time. So I sent off the defective unit along with my receipt and they have sent me a new one already! Very happy with the service and I hope they have gotten past the bad batch they were selling last year.   1447. This is a great product......when it works. I called Remington customer service 1-800-392-6544, the girl over the phone sounded like she set a trap when I brought up battery life, she asked how long I charged it, I told her 4 hours but I have left it for over 8 hours in the past with not much difference, she said I have to charge it 14 hours to get half an hour use out of it! it wont make a difference, even on a full charge, the point is even with no use, the battery just dies, I go back to use it 5 days after a full charge and it works for 20 seconds and dies, the Remington employee couldn't sounded like she gave less of an ish over the phone

Maybe it's my beard type, but I still have to resort to a 2 blade and shaving cream to really tighten things up.<br /><br />Comfortable to hold, decent ergonomics. Make sure you hold the length adjustment wheel firmly when taking the guide off or it will spin to a different setting, and you may not be aware of it the next time you go to trim your beard! Always check the length setting first! Learned this the hard way with an older electric trimmer! Went from beard to 5 o'clock shadow!<br /><br />Good razor overall.

  1505. This is easily the best beard trimmer I have come across, minus the battery issues I had with it. I have purchased 4 or 5 trimmers in the last year or so and this is the winner.<br />I purchased the Remington MB-200 a while back and after 18 months of use, the battery would not hold a charge anymore, so I was forced to buy a new one. I liked the trimmer so much I bought the same one again, even though the battery failed after just 18 months. The adjustable guard goes from 1-9 and gives you the ability to customize your beard however you like. I purchased the Braun Cruzer 5 Beard & Head Trimmer and the Andis Professional 04710 T-Outliner Personal Trimmer, and neither come close to the Remington MB-200.<br /><br />Pros: Adjustable guard works great, if you want to &#34;shape&#34; your beard this is the one for you.<br /><br />Cons: Battery gave out after 18 months, If you are looking for a trimmer to get close to your face, this is not the one.   1506. This trimmer cuts okay. I'm happy with the results I get. However, the battery in it really sucks. It doesn't last long at all, which means you basically have to keep it plugged in all of the time you are not using it.<br /><br />If you use it every day you probably won't notice a problem, but if you trim only once every week or two like I do, you'll notice problems. When you wait more than a week without charging it, the charge vanishes mid-shave. Every stroke, the pitch of the buzzing decreases, and it becomes impossible to finish a whole shave. When this happens, sometimes it grabs and pulls hairs instead of cutting them. Ouch!<br /><br />The problem with the battery would be manageable if the trimmer worked while plugged in. However, plugging it in doesn't alleviate the battery issue. You would hope that while plugged it, the trimmer would draw its power straight from the wall and deliver a strong cut, but it doesn't -- it keeps drawing from the battery, so you actually have to wait until the trimmer is fully charged again before it will deliver a strong cut. This can be a problem when you've shaved half of your face and then the trimmer dies, and you have to go to work soon...<br /><br />If you trim every day, you probably won't have any issues with this trimmer because you'll keep it charged. But I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Get a trimmer that doesn't rely on a battery for its performance instead.

  1517. Having bought this early in 2012, the battery already won't hold a charge. This wouldn't be a problem except the designer elected not to include circuitry that would allow it to run straight off mains power or charge the battery while plugged in.<br /><br />In other words, it's either running on the battery, or charging. So when the battery is dead (and die it will, as another reviewer notes, these seem to use obsolete NiCad cells) it's useless.<br /><br />Other problems:<br />-Flip-open mechanism to clean the blade assembly is very fragile<br />-Adjustment wheel (on mine at least) was a pain to turn<br /><br />You almost expect some issues with a relatively cheap beard trimmer, but the battery vs. mains thing is inexcusable; it speaks to deliberately designing it to be unusable altogether in a relatively short time.

  1520. Great trimmer... Until the battery dies after 6 months. I pulled the unit apart to try and change out the bad cells and found two AA size 600 mh nicads. This is probably everyones issue with the battery life. Changing out the cell to better cells was not possible. The charging circuit is not strong enough to accept better cells. I did replace them, but the shaver is now weak and does not perform as it did before. I have trashed it and am looking for something better. Complete waste of money. My last one lasted over 6 years.

  1549. The converter does not accept 240 voltage. That means you can't recharge it in most parts of the world.   1550. Long story short, the rechargeable battery on this trimmer is very poor. You have to charge it hours before you shave for it to work for more than 2 minutes. Forget about using this wirelessly at all. If you're fine with having this plugged in 24/7, then by all means, buy it.<br /><br />I have never really given anything a bad review on Amazon, as things can be easily researched in terms of quality. However, I made the mistake of buying this trimmer based on the other reviews here on Amazon. What a lot of them fail to mention is that this trimmer has to be plugged in at ALL times in order for it to be able to work for more than one minute. I often wanted to hide the cords for this trimmer, as it makes the sink look messy; I just wanted to get them out of the way. So I would unplug the trimmer from the outlet and leave it until the next time I had to shave.<br /><br />Problem was, the next time I would go to shave (say, a week later), the battery would be completely depleted. I would plug it in assuming it would work while plugged in. Nope. It works for about 30 seconds, then dies out and stops working.<br /><br />The solution to this was keeping it plugged in at least 2 hours before I needed to shave. I wasn't willing to do that. I shouldn't have to plan out my shaving habits and remember to plug this thing in 2 hours before every shave.
  1551. Was quite happy with this razor for about 4 months. Then the battery started dying, slowing lasting for shorter and shorter time periods. Eventually it just stopped holding a charge at all. And on top of that, the plug doesn't supply enough power to use the razor, so it's pretty much junk now. Disappointing.
  1552. I write this review on 1/15/15.<br /><br />I have now purchased this trimmer twice - once on 5/23/11, and most recently on 7/24/2013.<br /><br />The battery life on this is the big issue, as other reviewers have said. I swear, I remember having a Norelco that did the exact same thing in a similar style, and that thing lasted 3 years at least.<br /><br />Seeing that the MB-200 has once again died on me, I will be purchasing a Norelco QT4000/42.<br /><br />It really isn't a bad product for the price. It is easy to use, and will not break your bank - just don't grow super attached to it, cause you will need a new one shortly enough...
  1553. I should have paid attention to the negative &#34;charge problem&#34; reviews. Being a retired electronics tech, I know not to leave a NiCd battery device plugged in and charging. Nope, I treated it perfectly, letting the battery run down in use before charging - never leaving it plugged in. Still, it won't hold a charge.<br /><br />If it didn't trim well it would be a total piece of junk! Of course it won't hold a charge, it's still a total piece of junk!<br /><br />Don't get ripped off too, buy something else.
  1554. I have used it a little over 8 months now and it is still working well and I have been very happy with it. I use it almost everyday, although not for very long, and I rarely have to charge it. I do not have any of the poor battery issues that other reviewers are mentioning.
  1555. I like this unit - I owned a similar Remington model for several years, and was happy with the job it did. Other units I have tried in the past year have left me frustrated, so I was happy to purchase another Remington.<br /><br />However, one of the most attractive things about the newer model was that Amazon's product description page clearly stated that the head was washable. (In fact, this was stated more than once.) However, upon receiving the item, I find that the enclosed instructions specifically advise you not to rinse the cutter assembly under water. I know that the space under the cutter head can be cleaned with the supplied brush, but I find the process unpleasant.<br /><br />The other minor drawback to the MB-200 is that, unlike my older model, it cannot be operated with the cord attached. The adapter cord only recharges the batteries.<br /><br />So overall a good product, but not quite as advertised.
  1556. This trimmer performed well during the first year of use: sharp blades, fast, ergonomic, and easy to clean. After a year, the battery does not hold a recharge anymore, and you cannot used the trimmer connected to the power cord. I would not recommend this trimmer just because of the battery issue.
  1557. so far it works great, it's remington i think you are going to be satisfied with this one. it doesn't have many parts so i love it 'cos they wont get lost!
  1558. I broke my old razor so needed a new one fast, I had started to look too much like a lumberjack. I used the discover promo and It was delivered the same day! ordered bit past midnight Thursday (technically Friday) and it was waiting at my door by the time i got back from work. A quick charge and 5 min of grooming latter I once again looked presentable.<br /><br />The shaver is powerful enough to make shaving an ease and does not pull at hair at all. I am extremely happy with it and for the money and speed of delivery the deal can not be beat.

  1561. I bought this product over a year ago but only now needed to write a review. It has stopped holding a charge. When it worked it was great. Sharp, easy to use, easy to clean. I assume it is out of warranty.<br /><br />The rechargeable trimmer is very convenient, but I guess I will have to find a different company that uses better batteries.
  1562. Bought this because of the features and the price. I got what I paid for. Battery life has been miserably short since I purchased it in July of 2011. Even after being fully charged, I am lucky if I can trim my mustache and goatee before it dies on me. And of course, you all know how painful THAT can be! The battery life wouldn't have been an issue if it had some type of override, that would allow me to run it straight off the AC outlet. Guess I got a \\"lemon\\" based on all the positive reviews, but it will be hard to return as all the packaging was recycled some time ago. When I replace it, I will be looking for a better charging system, maybe a rechargeable lithium ion battery would be better. Or, I'll just find a model that plugs into the outlet, tho that limits portability. Will be somewhat leery of buying a Remington now...
  1563. I've used it for about 2 to 3 times per week, for about a month and a half without re-charging. It doesn't pull. I love this trimmer.
  1564. I am now on my third Remington MB-200. I have been using this trimmer since 2006, from the days of the old model.<br /><br />The old model lasted me three years, and would have lasted longer if I didn't lose it. The new models are the one that needs to be replaced every year or so, it seems. These trimmers are built cheap and they break quite easily (the hair-door at the front that you need to lift to clean hairs from underneath mostly). If they do not break, the battery will die on you first - currently my trimmer can't last more than three or four shavings without recharging.<br /><br />To be fair, I do use this trimmer for more than just facial hair: I use it to take haircuts (I am almost fully bald, so I just trim my head once in two weeks or so) as well as other parts (armpits, pubic hair) and it does do a great job, so I do use it almost on a daily basis.<br /><br />For the price, especially if I calculate how many trips to the barber it saves me, I can't really complain; however, I can't stop from thinking that perhaps for $10 more or so I could get a trimmer that does a much better job. I think this time around I'm going to try a different trimmer and see if there's a big difference.<br /><br />I'd say get this one if you want to do &#34;general&#34; hair treatment. Don't expect this piece to be too specific and get into the nooks of your face and curve the perfect beard, it is not going to happen. Use it for general &#34;damage control,&#34; if you get my drift.
  1565. After a year of use for trimming sideburns, doesn't keep a charge and you can not use while it is charging.
  1566. Super-easy beard and mustache trimming - just set dial from 1 to 9 and go. I think I've had to charge it once, maybe twice in 16 months or so. (;-) )<br /><br />Nov. 2013 update: batteries dying, not user-replaceable. Sucks that the device won't run off the power adapter; that is, with failing batteries, device useless.   1567. This trimmer worked great until the battery completely died and wouldn't hold a charge. For me it lasted a little less than a year before dying. You have to wait for it to actually charge.
  1568. This is a nice trimmer, I buy the same one once every five years or so when the battery won't hold a charge anymore. I won't cut my beard with anything else. It always stays sharp, and the blades are maintenance free, so you don't have to oil them.
  1569. This little trimmer ROCKS! It's still running strong, and I would have rated it five stars EXCEPT...<br /><br />The plastic hinged piece of the blade is broken, which is a small annoyance. I've even given myself a haircut with it. Not the best thing you ever saw, but it worked well enough. I imagine with practice you could give yourself a decent buzzcut with this.
  1570. This works great and keeps its charge for a long time. Its sharp and trims my beard perfectly. I would say though it seems to be a big jump between settings and 4 and 5. 5 being too long and 4 being too short. Not the end of the world but noticeable.

  1574. Admittedly, I've only had this product for a few days but this thing is great. The reason I had to buy it was because I accidentally dropped my last trimmer and it landed on its head and broke. It was time for a new one anyway. Funny thing is, when I opened the package for this trimmer, I did the exact same thing and dropped it (I'm normally not this clumsy, I swear). I was nervous to see the damage but there was none at all. This thing has a nice weight and feel, is obviously pretty durable, and the feature for the adjustable hair length is awesome. My last trimmer had separate attachments which proved to be a real pain so this was a great improvement. It takes about two or three passes to get my beard exactly how I'd like but I have yet to feel any pulls or tugs. Overall, this is a great value and I would definitely recommend it.<br /><br />UPDATE 5/9/2013<br />Unfortunately, after only four months of use my battery no longer holds a charge. Rather disappointing. This product was great while it lasted but what's the point if it's going to give out that quickly.
  1575. Tried to like it but just can't. Doesn't come with a stand, battery drains quickly, doesn't work while plugged in so if you drain the battery you have to wait until it's fully charged to use it. Overall I would not recommend this product. Am searching for a new trimmer now.
  1576. Battery gave out fairly quickly before it wouldn't hold a charge for less than five seconds. I had to open it up to fix and decided it wasn't worth spending the money to buy a new battery and solder it back on, instead I by passed the battery and applied 5V directly to the trimmer. Putting it together though was hard as once you open it stuff moves around because as aforementioned it is cheaply made. Would not recommend because it could not tolerate a once a week trim for a more than a few months. Also it cannot be used while charging so once you batteries blow you lose your trimmer essentially.
  1577. I purchased this for my husband, he loved it ! He had purchased two others, we returned them. He is very pleased with this product.
  1578. After years of having beard and using scissors and a lesser electric razor with only 3 settings, this is the best. The longest setting is over a 1/2 inch, longer than I would want it, and the shortest setting is almost a clean shave, so you have a lot of control over the length. There are a total of 9 lengths. This makes beard trimming very quick and easy. It is still running great after a year.
  1579. Pain in the neck because from the git go the battery will not stay up between uses. If I charge it and use it immediately it works fine, but if I charge it and set it aside for a couple of days, it's effectively dead when I get it out again.
  1580. I bought this trimmer in January as my beard was getting fairly long and I wanted it to get trimmed. I put it on the longest hair setting (9) and it starts taking off large swathes of hair. What gives, Remington? Playing around with the settings didn't help, it just got progressively shorter. But I wanted to keep my beard, not look like I had five o'clock shadow! So disappointed in this product. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.<br /><br />Edit: Have been using it to try and see if it would get better over time, and it now won't even charge. Less than 6 months to a DNR situation. I would warn anyone away from this product. Not only does it not work very well, it has the durability of something you'd buy at the flea market.<br /><br />Remember, this product only has a 60 day money back return policy. I made a mistake and tried to give it more of a chance. Big mistake! If you don't love this thing, return it and buy another company's brand. This one is not one you can trust.
  1581. I needed a beard trimmer and opted for this model over the newer lithium-ion model based on various reviews. First off, forget the reviews that say to get this model over the newer model because this one supposedly works better. I combed my beard thoroughly before using this trimmer, and it still pulled on my hairs painfully a few times whenever I shaved. It seemed to be a lot worse the longer my beard was.<br /><br />Second, if you use this trimmer more than twice a week or if you do a lot of trimming, you're not going to be happy with this one. The battery is about good enough for 2-3 longer sessions, or 10-12 quick trims, and since it's a NiCad battery, there's no such thing as quickly topping it off. You have to run the battery down to zero, then charge it for more than 12 hours. And of course, if you let it sit for a couple months without using it, it'll be dead anyway--so you need to plan at least a day in advance of ever wanting to use it. Since I rarely grow a beard, I suppose this will get me by, but anyone who trims their beard or mustache regularly is going to be annoyed at the battery's inconvenience.<br /><br />Third, the product listing on Amazon is inconsistent. In one place, it says this trimmer is rinsable, and in another place, it says it is not. As it turns out, this trimmer is absolutely not rinsable. It also does not include a detail head, which is included with at least one of the newer models in about the same price range.<br /><br />Overall, I'd say I'm disappointed in this trimmer. I knew ahead of time what sacrifices I was making, but other Amazon reviews had led me to believe the performance was so much better than other models that this one was worth it. It isn't as awesome as other reviewers have suggested, and it definitely wasn't worth the tradeoffs. I'd much rather have had the rinsable lithium-ion model with detail trimmer.
  1582. For the price, this was an ok investment. It is compact, but it doesn't hold a charge very well. If it's out of juice, you can't just plug it in and run it. You have to wait for it to charge and then run it. In addition, the beard trimmings go everywhere. In the end, the hassle of this device lead me to shave off my beard. It's easier to just shave in the shower, plus I look 10 years younger.
  1583. For the price this is the best trimmer I have ever had. It does a great job of trimming a beard and I have always found that difficult to get in a razor. Won't get you the closest shave but that is not what it is intended for. Every week I can trim My beard and this product was great!!!
  1584. I've enjoyed using this, however the battery does not last very long. Not the end of the world considering you can plug and shave.
  1585. Most beard trimmers are too bulky to trim the mustache the way I want. This trimmer can get super close under the nose and does the trick.

  1587. I had a similar previous model for 5+ years and it finally broke. So I bought this one thinking it was the same only new! ..Not so much. It needs to charge up before you can use it again. How stupid is that?! And my previous 5+ year older model was even able to operate directly from the wall plug even if it had no charge.   1588. These trimmers are amazing. They are extremely easy to adjust but very secure once you select your setting. In the past four years I have owned half a dozen pairs of beard trimmers and this one by far did the best job. Very even trim that I can not find on any other trimmers without having to spend too much time going over the same spot repetitively. I would love to give this item 5 stars<br /><br />Unfortunately these trimmers have an extremely short standby time and the charger does not give enough juice for these to run on a dead battery plugged in. Once charged and unplugged within as little as 24 hours it would not hold enough of a charge to be able to trim your beard. So unless you keep your trimmer plugged in constantly except when in use you will have this problem. I found myself never being able to trim or would start and then have to resort to hair clippers or shave completey because the battery would die. After so many times mine ended in pieces and I will never buy one again.

I just don't like that when it's charging it does not tell you if the battery is fully charged or not. I usually charge it for 10 hours, use it until it dies and then charge it again for another 10 hours.
